it's pretty hard to come up with a realistic & quantitative answer here. however, let's just say that among a pool of random startup companies the % is going to be pretty small, probably less than 1 in 100. if we then filter the set of candidates to be only those that have actually raised some money or have some decent traction -- say, those with at least $100K in funding, and/or $100K/year in revenue, then you might have at least single-digit % likelihood.

among our portfolio, we aim for 5-10% of our companies to have 20x or better outcomes, and another 20-30% of our companies to have 5x or better outcomes. still, we may not be that good.  my guess is that perhaps 1 to 3 in 10 of our entrepreneurs has a shot at a $1M payday and/or $10M+ exit at some point.

but the majority of them never have any exit whatsoever... it's a tough business.

1) most everyone on the 500 investment team is empowered to do deals, so you shouldn't take anyone for granted.

2) even folks who don't invest have significant influence on our deals, including other founders & mentors.

3) if you DO try to get to me or Christine, you'll find we are both busy as shit, and we will likely refer you back to our venture partners, mentors, or founders to get their opinions. 

4) if you try to work around or ignore the folks we send you to speak with, we will get pissed that you aren't respecting our process, and that you are essentially dissing the rest of our network. bad move, punk.

5) finally, even if you're working a traditional network that isn't 500, you'll find that gathering info & influence from non-decision makers can be helpful, and ignoring or trying to work around them can get them pissed / get you black-balled.

in short: the conventional wisdom that non-partners can't say "yes" and can only say "no" is perhaps true, but naive in the sense that getting a deal done often involves a number of influencers who are *not* decision-makers. 

ignore them at your peril... especially at 500 Startups.

yes, in fact many angel investors probably aspire to become VCs... usually because we're not very rich. typically, the independence of an angel investor is much more desirable than having all the fiduciary responsibilities of a VC who manages OPM ("Other People's Money"). however, for most angel investors who don't have $10-100M to invest, raising a fund may be the only way for them to acquire the necessary capital to do significant # investments.

for me personally, i started off doing angel investing around 2003-2004 with about $300K that i had from selling some stock options while i was at PayPal (2001-2004), and i invested in about 2-4 deals per year at between $10-100K, or about 1 deal every 3-4 months at around $25K.  however, i wasn't very thoughtful on my allocation strategy, and invested over 1/2 my available capital in the first year. then later, I was stretching to do investments at even $5-10K in the last few years. a few times, i did part-time consulting to make money so I could do more investing -- once i even sold my wife's car in order to get money to do a deal! (insert crackhead/alcoholic joke here). however, regardless of process I was fortunate to invest in several companies that later had decent exits of ~10x or more, including Slideshare, Mint.com, and Mashery.

even though I made a lot of mistakes, I learned a lot and it was a useful apprenticeship to go through before starting my own fund. there were many things about legal structure, company formation, founder-investor interaction, and other topics that i knew little about when i started investing, even though i considered myself a knowledgeable software engineer & internet marketing geek. i'm sure i wouldn't have had enough experience to do VC investing without going through this period, as well as later working at Founders Fund.

in any case, by 2007-2008 i realized my angel investments were going to take awhile to mature, and soon i was going to run out of money to invest! so the only way i could keep doing investing was to raise my own fund, or join another firm. altho i was planning to setup a small fund of $5-10M to get started, my timing sucked -- trying to raise even a small amount of capital in summer 2008 turned out to be very challenging (due to the financial crisis in aug/sept 2008), and as a result i wasn't able to raise my own fund (yet).

but as luck would have it, my alternative wasn't so bad -- i was fortunate to get a job offer from Sean Parker (thx Sean!) at Founders Fund to help them with marketing, and i was also able to convince him/them to let me manage a small ~$2-3M portfolio of early-stage investments. besides being perhaps the only person hired in Venture Capital in Q4 2008, i was extremely lucky as a rookie VC to get the [very unusual] opportunity to make over 40 small investments in the ensuing year and a half. Companies that I got to invest in included Twilio, SendGrid, Wildfire, Credit Karma, Lyft (then Zimride), and TaskRabbit, among several others that went on to both small & larger success (as well as bunch that didn't). overall, i did ok on investing -- maybe more lucky than good, but well enough they didn't fire me.

after investing on behalf of Founders Fund and the Facebook fbFund (which i also managed for a period of time in 2009), and after the market recovered in 2010, i was able to finally convince a group of investors (which included Founders Fund & a few other VCs and entrepreneurs) to help back my first fund. in late July of 2010, we did the first closing of 500 Startups Fund I, and eventually we did a final closing at slightly over $29M. and we were off to the races.

note: these days, I'd recommend aspiring angels & VCs check out the Syndicates feature on Angel List, which allows more active angel investors to coordinate funds from other investors, without all the initial complexity and legal hassle / cost of raising a fund. (see http://AngelList.co for more info)

in summary:
- raising a venture capital fund is hard, but possible if you keep at it -- even if you aren't super-rich, and even if you haven't had a $100M+ exit
- many angel investors aspire to be venture capitalists, usually because it will bring them access to larger amounts of capital to invest (& perhaps more vanity / marketing visibility too)
- investing Other People's Money (OPM) is VASTLY different from investing your own money, and carries with it a number of new, different, and far more complex responsibilities
- be careful what you wish for, you might just get it ;)

most of our negotiation tactics aren't very advanced or thoughtful. we'd rather not be known for being too smart at negotiating, but rather for being helpful.

generally speaking: we try hard to be useful and transparent to most of our companies, and as a result we hope they treat us right and don't fuck us over.

that said, when we feel like people are negotiating hard with us, we will probably match that behavior. if they don't feel the need to do that, then we probably won't either.

a few things we do consider important:
- we are pretty sensitive to valuation, but we don't care much about ownership; since we are usually a small-check investor relative to other participants, and our value-add is rated highly by most founders, most folks will cut us a break on valuation & this is part of our strategy.
- we always ask for information rights & [some] pro-rata rights, so that we can understand how the company is doing, and so we can invest in future rounds if the things are going well. note that we don't usually play a lead role in most financings, but we do follow-on in a minority role often.
- in convertible note financings, we typically ask for a minimum 2x return clause in case the company sells prior to a priced round. we believe this is a reasonable ask that is becoming a market standard, since we aim to make a venture return and we aren't bankers... we're not trying to fuck with you.
- in cases where there is a talent acquisition or small exit, we know we won't likely have much leverage... however if founders are walking away with a decent payday (say, more than a million bucks) then we hope you won't forget how we supported you in the beginning, and we hope you won't let acquirers (or other investors) fuck us over. still, we know it will happen. but don't expect us to forget when it does. in return, we will do our best not to be assholes.

in summary: most games aren't zero sum, and we'd rather be the nice guy and finish the race with a smaller percentage of the stakes and our reputation intact, than vice versa. so we try hard to be transparent & earnest. this does not mean we are pushovers, however, and we are in this to make money. as noted above, we do remember when people fuck with us... and also, when they do not.

it's really pretty simple: don't be an asshole, and we won't be either.

actually, we've now made over 500 investments, probably sometime a few months back.  the name is our brand, not a goal.

there are several factors that influence our opinion of teams that apply for 500 Startups... they usually break down as follows:

0) objective, provable evidence you are awesome, that is indisputable & does not depend on anyone's opinion (ex: "i sold a company for $100M, i created Ruby, i built an Eiffel Tower model out of popsicle sticks when i was 7")

if there isn't objective proof, then we like to hear first-hand references that you're awesome, ideally from people we know, and ideally in a work situation:

1) are there existing "500 Family" (our team, our founders, or mentors) who have had a positive WORK-ing relationship with you, and are willing to comment positively about your skills / experience?
2) alternately, are there 500 Family members who have a NON-working or personal relationship with you, and will comment positively?
3) alternately are there non-500 Family members who have a WORK-ing relationship with you, and will comment positively?
4) is there ANYONE who will say ANYTHING positive, regardless of whether they've worked with you?

in summary, we care about:
0) indisputable, objective proof that you're awesome, OR
1) people in 500 Family who will reference a positive working relationship, OR
2, 3) other non-500 people OR other non-work relationship, OR
4) anyone who thinks you smell nice & aren't a complete idiot (like, your mom)

note: 0 or 1 is best.

(while we think your mom is nice, we probably don't trust her that much... sorry ;)

I met him online in 2000, and then over the last half dozen years I saw him in person several times. Sometimes one-on-one, sometimes at conferences.

So we were friends, but we were not close friends.

Aaron was quiet and introspective. He was an active listener.

He was very smart but never made me feel bad for not being as smart as him. He was patient in explaining things to me. He was creative -- in talking with him, I'd usually get a great idea I had not considered.

He was kind and thoughtful. He thought about the consequences of whatever we were talking about. He had a subversive side, but it had a purpose.

Despite being outspoken, he was introverted -- most of our interactions were because I wrote to him. He had great follow through. Always wrote back.

I gladly did favors for him whenever I could. Not because he ever asked me for help, but because talking with him inspired me and made me want to help any way I could.

I am still inspired by him. I feel that my life is better having met him, and it makes me sad that he left this world so soon.

is Hello, I'm Adam Rifkin, and I co-founded PandaWhale with Joyce Park in 2011.

We are building PandaWhale.com to expand the public Web.

We help people who find gold nuggets floating in their social streams to publish those things back to the public Web -- where they can be found by others with the same interests.

We have two use cases:

Writers are people who save interesting things they find, and comment on the things other writers are stashing.
Readers are over 99% of PandaWhale's users. They are free to lurk all they want without logging in, and share PandaWhale discoveries on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Pinterest, LinkedIn, Google+, and other networks.

PandaWhale gives our writers tools to organize their own stashes, which are collections around interests.

PandaWhale gives our readers tools to follow any individual stashes, which lets them receive notifications when new interesting things are stashed.

PandaWhale's main competition is publishing to a blog. We believe that blogging is great, but it puts pressure on an author to maintain that blog all the time; by pooling the content we find together with a great community, PandaWhale's writers only post when we find something interesting. Our community is fun and loves to learn.

You are welcome to join us on PandaWhale.com any time.

It's possible KPCB can repair its reputation with some people, but there are entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley who will never consider an investment from KPCB as a result of not only the allegations but also the way KPCB has handled itself since May 10, when the lawsuit was filed.

I found this article from Dan Primack of Fortune informative: http://finance.fortune.cnn.com/2...

The article states that:

1. KPCB did not disclose the lawsuit to its limited investors "because any awarded damages would almost certainly represent less than 10% of the firm's assets under management." In other words, KPCB sees this as a financial matter, not a culture matter or a values matter.

2. The lawsuit will not get resolved anytime soon. This will create ongoing tension within KPCB -- "If not, then the firm is staffed by robots."

3. Entrepreneurs try to find the best partners for its businesses. This will weigh heavily in their decision to even consider KPCB at all: "Even if Kleiner Perkins is able to mitigate certain specifics via its legal response -- or quickly reach an out-of-court settlement -- the word in Silicon Valley today is that the firm treats some of its female partners as inferiors (or worse). The suit also suggests that Kleiner has, at least once, put a partner on a portfolio company board more for that partner's own ego than for the company's best interests."

I've talked with many entrepreneurs this week at several startup events who have taken KPCB off the list of firms they would consider for investment. They will not say so in public because they fear retribution against their startups for taking a stand.

For them, KPCB will not regain its reputation unless it takes steps like the ones mentioned in Anon User's answer ...

And for all of us who are appalled by gender discrimination, the lawsuit has increased awareness that Silicon Valley has a problem. This gives us the opportunity to double down on our efforts to break the glass ceilings of our industry: http://gigaom.com/2012/05/24/can...

tl;dr : Kleiner Perkins has an opportunity to change their reputation, but there are significant risks to their ability to do so.

I'm writing the following with no insight into their organization other than my own experiences with them in the past.

My first instinct is that Kleiner Perkins has a great opportunity to establish themselves as a leader with KPCB 15.

Kleiner Perkins led the "A" round of my first startup in 2000 (KnowNow; real-time Web enterprise software), and at that time they were a clear leader in software investing, having been the earliest venture investor in billion-dollar companies like Netscape, Amazon, and Google.

When I visited Kleiner Perkins for the first round of my second startup in 2005 (Renkoo; social consumer Web apps), partners there told me that they were more interested in Life Sciences and Green Technology than Internet startups.

What's interesting is that they passed over a lot of software deals in 2005 and 2006, just as software was starting to get huge again.

They watched as other firms got a great reputation investing in the early rounds of software companies that would later be worth more than $1 billion:
Greylock (Facebook, LinkedIn, Pandora, Airbnb, Tumblr);
Sequoia (YouTube, LinkedIn, Tumblr, Dropbox, Square);
Benchmark (Twitter, Instagram);
USV (Twitter, Tumblr, Zynga);
Bessemer (Yelp, Pinterest); and
Accel (Facebook, Groupon, Rovio), just to name a few examples.

Those software companies that Kleiner Perkins did get into early -- startups like Zynga, Flipboard, Path, and Klout -- were unusual choices. Among them, only Zynga has become a billion dollar company, and even then, Kleiner led the second round, not the first.

When Kleiner Perkins did invest in software companies like Facebook and Twitter and Groupon, they did so very late, after each of those companies were worth roughly $15 billion, $4 billion, and $6 billion, respectively.

So Kleiner Perkins now has a reputation in the startup circles I visit as a late-stage software investor.

But that can change. And clearly the firm wants to change.

Now, with KPCB15's focus, Kleiner Perkins has an opportunity to change their reputation back to an excellent early-stage software investor.

In particular, hiring Mike Abbott as managing director was a very smart move that substantially and immediately increases the firm's ability to attract the best young software startups. Entrepreneurial engineers want to work with him. Either of his first two investments -- Gumroad and Apcera -- could become billion-dollar companies, and they chose Kleiner Perkins because they wanted to work with Michael Abbott.

That's a great start. Hopefully Kleiner Perkins will continue to evolve in that direction, and make more early investments in software startups that could be huge.

What are the key risks for Kleiner Perkins right now?

Arrogance. Kleiner Perkins has a reputation for congratulating itself; many people in many Silicon Valley circles have told me this over the years. For an example, see Anonymous' answer to Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers: How is Kleiner Perkins regarded today?
The Sexual Harrassment Lawsuit. We don't know all the details and likely never will, and we don't know if Kleiner Perkins will win the suit. Public perception is likely damaged just by lawsuit itself. See also: Ellen Pao/KPCB Sexual Harassment Lawsuit: Will Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers be able to regain its reputation after Ellen Pao's sexual harassment lawsuit?

I've said it at the beginning and I'll conclude with it, too: Kleiner Perkins has an opportunity to change their reputation, but there are significant risks to their ability to do so.

Update. It's now almost a year since I got mine and I find my utility going down because Google has not yet fixed the major problems.

Voice response only works if you have a connection. Often I'm in a place, like Yellowstone, that has no connectivity.
You can only put 10 contacts into Glass, so making calls much more difficult than it should be.
You can't see, edit, or caption photos in Glass easily (only voice commands, which don't work in noisy situations like concerts). No way to automatically push photos from Glass to your smartphone, which would make it a LOT easier to edit, etc.
Facebook and Instagram and Twitter apps inadequate for really doing great posts.
No store, so getting apps very difficult.
Voice control of directions is usually good, but when it makes an error it is very hard to fix.
No live video streaming yet.
Battery life continues being too short, particularly when shooting video (I only get about 40 minutes when recording video).
Video compression is being done in software, not hardware, so unit gets hot, video isn't very high quality, and battery dies in 45 minutes or less.
Video only goes to a special part of Google+ (a new version of YouTube) and you can't easily push it to other places, like Vimeo, or your existing YouTube account.
The price is still at least twice as expensive as the most expensive smartphone and doesn't work without a smartphone. Until the price comes down I'll advise most people to stay away, especially given the lack of utility at the moment (and the risks that the UI and API's will dramatically shift this year).

There are other problems, as well, that keep it from being very useful. When I wrote the post below I thought Google would fix the problems quickly. I keep hoping fixes are coming.


++++++++++++++++++

I have had a Google Glass for two weeks now and they are VERY useful. Here's my review: My two-week review of Google Glass: it all depends on the?

Why? Well, just yesterday I was walking my kids around in a stroller. Both hands were on the stroller. Yet I was able to have New York Times articles read to me, I took a phone call (and made one to my wife), and I took a photo of the experience too.

This product is life changing. By the way, the Glass can NOT broadcast live to the world yet. You can shoot a video, have it uploaded to a private area on Google+, and only then can you move it over to public view from your smartphone or from inside the Glass itself.

After showing them to hundreds of people, I think the threats are mostly perception issues: if you walk into the wrong kind of bar, or a bathroom or gym locker room with them on, you might suffer consequences that won't be fun.

The big usefulness, though, is that these assist you living your life. When I got to the airport the other day it told me the gate and time of my flight. Very useful. Google Now also tells me other stuff, like how bad the traffic is on the way to work, etc. That's where the real functionality is.

Easy. Walk into any restaurant. Look at how many people are holding a mobile phone. Now consider that about a billion people are getting smartphones this year alone. Second, look at adoption rates of new things on laptops vs. mobile. Mobile is way higher. Third, look at numbers at some place like Facebook -- mobile is passing desktop usage.

I often sit next to people who use Windows PCs and I ask them "show me something you've put on your computer that's new, loaded in the past couple of weeks." Out of hundreds of people most can't answer that. Ask a mobile user the same thing and they'll take you on a tour of their apps "oh, just got this Dots game, or check out the new Nest app I just got, etc etc."

The tech press and investors care about where the market is going. Where is growth happening. Where are the most interesting, new, apps?

In my world: mobile, mobile, mobile, mobile.

I get way more requests than I can take. Here's a few things I do:

1. I have an out-of-office message on Gmail that gives me the permission not to answer you (no answer is an "automatic no" the email says). Here's that email -- that lets me avoid being a jerk just by not replying:

++++++++++++++

Thank you for taking the time to write to me and I'm sorry if I don't get back to you.

I'm now getting emails at a level that I can't respond to everyone. This is an automatic response to an email you sent to scobleizer@gmail.com.

I will make a best attempt to get back to you, especially if you are sharing world-changing technology or if you are building contextual software or services, since I wrote a book with Shel Israel on that trend. Our book, "Age of Context," has been released at Age of Context: Mobile, Sensors, Data and the Future of Privacy eBook: Robert Scoble, Shel Israel: Kindle Store

I also am looking for best-of-breed tools to help people build companies on top of cloud infrastructure, due to my role at Rackspace.

I do read every email, but I only can reply to about 5%, sorry.

Unfortunately if I don't answer you within two or three days, it's the same as hearing "no."

To PR people, if you want me to cover your product you've got to give me more than one day warning.  I don't do press-release rewrites like other tech bloggers. It's best to get in touch with me at LEAST A MONTH before you launch.

If you are looking for more about where I'm publishing, or just want to have an informal chat, visit Robert Scoble | Facebook which has links to all of my blogs, and social media accounts.

Another way to get through is to talk with my producer, Rocky Barbanica. You can reach him at rocky@rackspace.com.

Thanks and sorry if I don't get back to you.

++++++++++++++

2. Have a philosophy. Mine is contextual computing is going to be more and more interesting. So, if you aren't contextual (mobile first) and using sensors, wearable computers, etc, then I will be less interested in you. This lets me say no in a nice way. "Sorry, I'm looking for a specific kind of interaction in 2014 and you don't fit."

3. Have a boss who makes you say no due to other interests. Boss's don't need to be employers, either. My kids and wife are in charge of my life too and demand my time the same as others do. "My wife won't let me fit that speech into our calendar, sorry." Or, "my kids haven't seen me for a month so I can't make that dinner, sorry." Works just as well as "my boss at Rackspace already signed me up for another speech that evening, sorry."

4. Know what you want out of life. I want to have more three-star Michelin-rated dinners. So, if you offer me one of those I'll find it very hard to turn down. I also want to see the next big company when it's just two entrepreneurs at a table. I find it hard to turn down a chance to see another company, particularly one that has an interesting new product coming out.

5. Try to be helpful in some other way. "Hey, I can't do that interview you wanted me to do because I'm already booked this week, how about I introduce you to some other journalists who can help?"

6. Suggest ways to get to success. Those who are busy are very transactional. So, asking for coffee might get turned down, while asking to meet to pitch might not. Coffee implies some sort of squishy social agenda. "I don't do coffee, but if you have a pitch please email me that." Often they really just wanted to pitch you anyway and were trying to be nice by asking to buy you coffee.

7. If the person sounds interesting to at least meet, suggest meeting at an event "hey, I'm about to head to CES in Vegas, will you be there or at SXSW in March?"

8. Be honestly busy. My calendar is 100% filled for January now. I'm very happy to show you my Google Calendar, which demonstrates that well. So, saying "I'm booked until February and not booking new things" works.

9. Ask them to go through someone who has an easier time saying no. For instance, I have a producer, Rocky Barbanica. He is far more willing to say no than I am. That said, if you convince him, it usually is because you actually have something great, so I'm more willing to put you on the calendar after you get through him.

10. Push them over to a social network. I do that because I want to be scalable in everything I do (answering a question on Quora, for instance, helps out potentially thousands of people, while answering a question in email only helps one person out). So, saying "ask that question on Quora" is a good way to turn down people. Smart people use Facebook to see when I'm online, too (I'll often chat with you there before answering my own email).

UPDATE: a friend, Loic Le Meur, turned down my request by saying simply "I'll be on Necker Island then." (That's the island that Richard Branson owns). I'll add that as #11: be doing something far cooler than what is being offered. :-)

I would say that you should contact a tech journalist only AFTER you do this:

Know and follow at least 50 (I have a list of 600+ tech journalists on Twitter at Tech News People).
Make sure your startup might be interesting to the journalist in question.
Know why said tech journalist MIGHT cover you and HOW he/she might cover you (IE, have an interesting story). If I was trying to get into the New York Times, for instance, I'd read at least 500 articles written there first and I'd even start putting them into buckets. Know what bucket yours will go in.
Know how your startup is better than other companies already on the field.

Remember that, in my case, I only can accept about 1% of what gets pitched to me. I'm looking for companies who are pushing the future forward. That's vague, but not really. scobleizer@gmail.com is generally the best but phone can work too. +1-425-205-1921 -- know when I'm online and available, you can tell this from Facebook, in my case: https://www.facebook.com/RobertS...

Some tips?

Keep it short.
Explain why you are an example of how the future is changing.
Bring up anything that backs up your story (for instance, do you have a famous developer who already changed the world at, say, Apple?)
Make it easy to dive in. Do you have a blog? A video? A bunch of people talking about you on Twitter or Google+ or Facebook? A successful Kickstarter or Indiegogo campaign?
Work hard on a great headline. Lots of us get 1,000 press releases a day. Think about how to stand out.
Get someone we trust to refer you. If Marc Andreessen emails me and says "Scoble, you gotta see this new company" you bet your bottom dollar I'll stop and pay attention.
ALWAYS carry your demo on your phone or iPad and be willing to show in weird places. Accidental PR is the best. I've found many of my favorite companies away from "official PR."
Be persistent, but not overbearing. Sometimes trying a second try when you have something new to announce works. I don't know why. It's just the luck of the draw. The difference between being persistent and being overbearing is a very thin line, though. Be good at listening to feedback.
If in a crowded market (photo sharing services, for instance) you better be 10x better and you better be able to demonstrate that in 30 seconds or less. Google was the 17th search engine but in just one search I was hooked and saw why it was better.

Some don'ts?

Don't mix social and business. If you want to just hang out with us and be our friend, that's OK, but don't try to "buddy up" just to get a chance to pitch me. Our social time is for socializing, not work.
Don't ask to pitch. The answer is ALWAYS no. Instead, ask something like "I have a ground-breaking iPad app that is 10x better than Microsoft Office, what do you need to verify that what I'm telling you is true?"
Don't pitch us without looking at our Twitter and Facebook (even better if you use a tool like Nimble.com that shows you everything about us) . I have gotten a pitch right after I learned my mom was dying (I wrote about that online).
If you meet me in the street, don't try to pitch me unless you have some very unusual social proof (like if you are hanging out with Marc Andreessen and he verifies that what you are building is the best thing he's seen this year). I never remember these "street" pitches and they rarely are any good anyway. Instead, introduce yourself, and ask for our email so that you can pitch us professionally.
Don't pitch us on Facebook, LinkedIn, or Twitter. Email is best for a whole lot of reasons (at least in my case). If you do pitch us there you'll get instructions to pitch us on email (mine is scobleizer@gmail.com ). I hate these social pitches because I can't easily search for them in the future and I often don't have time to answer everyone everywhere so focus on my email first.

I always want to be on the bleeding edge, or, more accurately use tools that are "best of breed." For the past seven years that was Apple's iPhone which is, still, arguably the best mobile ecosystem out there. Apps still ship on iPhone first (generally) and when I look at tech passionate people most of them still have iPhones and iPads.

That said, things are switching. Read Paul Stamatiou, designer at Twitter, about his experiences with Android: Android is better I agree with all his points.

My view started shifting last year when I saw a new series of trends that, bundled up, bring us contextual computing (I'm writing a book on those trends with Shel Israel, titled "Age of Context" that will come later this year).

Most of the apps in this new field are on Android first because of Android's more open approach. A great example is Everything.me - Introducing the Dynamic Phone TM, which is my favorite app switcher. It can change nearly everything about the phone and hook into all your apps, even. Things that are impossible for developers to do on iOS.

These new contextual apps, including Google Now, got me to look at Android in a new light. No longer was it an uglier cousin of iOS but was bringing very real innovation to bear.

Then, when Google Glass came out, my mind totally switched. I was  one of the first in line at last year's Google IO conference to lay down $1,500 for my own Google Glass (I've been wearing them every day since April 16, 2013).

Google Glass is a real game changer. No other consumer electronics device knows where I'm aimed, where I'm looking, and has such a consistent access to my context through the sensors inside.

Of course it works better with Android (it runs Android 4.0.4 inside). So that pushed me to make the switch.

Later, Moto X showed me that there's yet again, more innovation coming on the Android side of the fence (you can't talk to your iPhone without touching it first), but on Moto X it just listens for you to say "OK Google Now." Since it is illegal to touch a phone while driving, both Glass and Moto X are big deals for me since I drive 1.5 hours every day to the Rackspace Studio in San Francisco and back.

That all said, I still have an iPad and am watching the Apple ecosystem closely. Most users won't follow me, there aren't enough advantages -- yet. But with Paul's note, and my observations, there is something happening on the Android side of the fence and I think it'll become more obvious next year that Android has taken the innovation crown away from Apple (and everyone else).

It's expensive because the ones that are being distributed now are prototypes that are being built one-by-one.

I expect that when they are released to the public next year they will be somewhere around $200 to $300. The build-of-materials is somewhere around $100, when you look at all the components. Of course that doesn't cover the millions of dollars spent in R&D and in acquiring people, like Thad Starner, to come and build them.

Some reasons they are so expensive (this isn't the first time a company has charged a lot for developer prototypes -- the Xbox prototypes were about the same price):

Supply and demand. They can only make a few hundred per week at this point. So, having a low price wouldn't make sense. When you have very little supply and a lot of demand, raising the price is perfectly reasonable.
Making sure that the best people get them first. If I were Google I'd want mostly developers to have them at this point so that there'd be some apps when they are released early in 2014. Developers see the value in building companies and products to target a new platform. Paying $1,500 to build something like Instagram won't seem significant in three years if the business is successful. Most other people won't see the value in paying $1,500 for an unproven new gadget.
PR reasons. If you spend $1,500 for a pre-release prototype you know what you are getting into. You'll likely give a lot of feedback to Google. You'll likely understand the limitations (there are MANY app holes right now, for instance) and forgive those. Regular people, if they got them at this point, wouldn't understand those limitations and would complain about them on Twitter and Facebook, etc.
Anyway, I think this is a short term problem. By May most people will be able to buy them and I can't see a reason that Google would charge more than $500 for them (and I can see many that they would want to make them very low cost, like $200).

I work for Rackspace and have for 4.5 years.

It is the best-run company I have ever worked for in my 48 years of life.

It is also very well positioned for the next Contextual Age of business (where sensors, wearable computers, mobile devices, along with social and location data, are going to totally change how businesses work with customers and each other).

Why?

Out of all the companies mentioned only Rackspace is built on open source cloud technology. That means we'll be able to do more things, and not lock our customers in, like the others do.

For instance, can you run AWS on your own datacenters? Or on your own machine on your desk? No. But with OpenStack you can (OpenStack is a fully open source foundation, so you can innovate without waiting for someone else to do it).

Look at it another way. With Rackspace you are safe to move to another provider built on top of OpenStack. Can you say the same about the others? No. You are locked in.

Add in the fanatical support that Mark talks about, and I'm quite optimistic about the future of Rackspace.

Why would you bet against open source? Do you like having to wait for big companies to innovate? Do you like being locked in? Do you like not having the choice of where to run your cloud?

Most of the time? Nothing.

But IF (big if) you all are on the "OK Glass" screen, then it'll listen to the first voice it hears. So, one person is able to, say, shoot a picture on everyone's Glass if they yell "OK Glass, Take a Picture."

Now, in real world? If someone did that around me I'd instantly turn my Glass off by pulling down on the touch surface.

Also, if you try something funnier like "Send a message" it won't work unless you know which of the 10 people I've added to the contact list on Glass. Also, like I said, if you try to do something funny I'll just turn it off before it has a chance to send a message to someone.
I still love it, even after wearing it for two months every day.

Define success.

It has already become part of my life permanently. That's success in my book.

Will it sell a million units? That depends on the price. $199 hell yes. $499 hell no.

Will it be used by my dad? I doubt it. It took me two years to convince him to switch his search engine from Alta Vista to Google.

So, please, define success.

It has already succeeded at making other companies look non-innovative.

As to whether I have ANYTHING to do with its success or failure? That's laughable. It makes for great headlines, but you really think anyone out there won't buy this because I took a photo with it in the shower? If anything, that sold more Google Glass because it demonstrates very effectively that it survives in rainstorms. It also shows that those of us who have it can laugh at ourselves and not take life SO damn seriously!

At one of those awful startup launch parties*, overrun with founders and engineers and investors and random busty girls hired to 1. improve the male:female ratio, 2. wear the host company's tshirt, and 3. get the dance floor started?no joke; to me and my female engineer friend, upon introducing ourselves as working at Quora, a male engineer from another well-known startup offered this amazing conversation starter: "So, what do you guys do? like, photocopy shit?"**

No, asshole, we are engineers, and your billion dollar founder personally tried to recruit both of us, so shut it.

* Yay, networking for professional advancement!
** All things considered, this doesn't rank that highly in the most misogynistic or chauvinistic things that men have said to women, but anybody who thinks there isn't sexism in Silicon Valley is horribly mistaken.

I set up a Github project at triketora/women-in-software-eng to crowdsource data on this subject (the data populates this spreadsheet, from which Ri Liu has built this visualization). As of April 2014, data from 149 companies has been submitted, for a total of 4700+ engineers counted. Overall, the percentage of female engineers in this data set is somewhere between 12 and 13%.

To answer the question, then:

The companies that have 1 out of 1 or 2 out of 2 female engineers technically have the highest percentages, but these are small numbers and very unstable. They just need to hire one or two men for their percentages to plummet. There's a lot of noise at the small company side of the spectrum.

At scale, the numbers start to reflect the underlying lack of diversity in tech, and it is harder to maintain higher percentages. Only counting companies with 50+ total engineers, the percentage of female engineers in the sample drops from 12.7% to 10.5%. In this set of companies, the ones that have above-average representation of female engineers are New Relic (19.87%), Rhapsody (18.42%), SurveyMonkey (17.31%), Guideware Software (17.21%), Practice Fusion (16.67%), Rdio (16.07%), Pinterest (14.39%), Quantcast (13.39%), Airbnb (13.16%), and Etsy (12.75%).

Note: People quibble quite a bit about who is considered an engineer or developer. I've gotten some flak about not counting some types of technical work as engineering (e.g. sysadmin, CSS), but the line has to be drawn somewhere. Any question like this is hard to answer "accurately" and to everyone's satisfaction.

Pinterest is a great place to work, full stop; but there are also many reasons to recommend it as a place to work as a front-end engineer:

The web product is what put Pinterest on the map and, even with the advent of mobile, is still critically important to the company as one of the major touch points with Pinners and partners. The work of front-end engineers at Pinterest is valued and has high impact.

pinterest.com is a hefty piece of engineering. We are no longer just building a website; we are building a full-featured web application, and there is a lot of complexity in that. At the platform level, we've developed a new web framework with modularity and reusability as first-class design principles, and built to consume the Pinterest API like any other client. We're still extending that framework (and the core abstractions on it), making it more powerful, performant, and easy to develop on. And of course the product itself is just really fun to build out -- features like place boards and place Pins require some pretty awesome front-end wrangling:

http://www.pinterest.com/triketora/tech-offices/

A strong company culture of "knitting" means product design and front-end engineers work very closely together to develop the user-facing product. And our designers are truly world-class and forward-thinking: the proliferation of the Pinterest grid layout across the modern web is just one indication of how we're pushing the field towards new standards. It's quite a privilege to work with such creative thinkers, and we really do work together. Designs aren't just set and tossed over a wall for implementation; engineers are also big stakeholders in "putting pinners first" (our #1 company value) and work hard to make the user experience great.

The team is phenomenal: deeply talented, with complementary strengths and backgrounds, and a dedication to collaboration and mentorship. I joined the web team at Pinterest with virtually no prior experience in web development; I couldn't have found a better team to bring me up to speed. Every pull request I submitted, I'd tag @Pinterest/web, and I'd get really helpful and insightful feedback on everything from alternate implementations with an analysis of tradeoffs, browser performance considerations, JS and CSS best practices, etc.

For those interested in exploring more full-stack work, there is also the opportunity to join full-stack product teams, doing front-end engineering for particular features but also delving into other/new technical domains. A couple of web team alums, myself included, have moved onto such teams, while retaining close ties to the web team.

Security firm Codenomicon is to credit for the branding job of the Heartbleed bug, otherwise known as CVE-2014-0160. (The firm discovered the bug independently of but simultaneously as Google security researcher Neel Mehta.) An engineer at Codenomicon coined the name, the company registered the domain, and Codenomicon designer Leena Snidate came up with the logo.

The semantic relationship of the name "Heartbleed" to the bug is that the bug lies in the TLS protocol "heartbeat" mechanism, used to assure a machine that its peer is still alive and available on the network, and the bug "bleeds" data.


Source: Why The Security Bug Heartbleed Has A Catchy Logo

At 13 years old, boys and girls have already been exposed to 13 years of socialization encouraging in boys and discouraging in girls an interest in computers.


Unlocking the Clubhouse[1] has by far the best treatment of this topic that I've seen in the literature -- the authors conducted over 230 interviews with over 100 male and female computer science students at Carnegie Mellon from 1995 to 1999, weaving together quantitative and qualitative data to construct a picture of this ever leaky pipeline of women in computing, and the STEM fields generally.

(By way of brief summary of relevant research from that book, any mis-interpretations or mis-representations my own: ) From childhood, there's plenty going on in the home to perpetuate this gender divide. It's not just the types of toys that parents choose for their children, sometimes reflecting parental projections of their children's preferences more so than their actual preferences. There's also generationally-inherited gender bias when dad/son time and mom/daughter time reflect what dad and mom, respectively, like to do. And gender norms established when dad tinkers on the computer and mom is content to be "computer illiterate"; when the family computer is placed not in the daughter's room but in the son's room, with the implicit ownership that that implies; when girls are held back from wandering  or exploring too far physically or metaphorically.

In the classroom and in social settings, boys and girls quickly learn which activities and spaces are male-appropriate and which are female-appropriate. Playing with computers and hanging out in the computer lab fall squarely on the male side of that dividing line.


The marketing machine of modern capitalism contributes handily to these social expectations as well. For example, gaming is often tipped as a gateway activity to computing, and it's a heavily gendered one -- thanks to marketing. After a big crash in the video game industry in the 1980s, the industry tightened and refocused its marketing efforts to target boys and young men. The message became "No girls allowed", because it was deemed a more successful market strategy, and it's become a self-fulfilling prophecy.[2]

Broadening our perspective to other building blocks of pop culture, movies like The Social Network and TV shows like "Big Bang Theory" (both of which, incidentally, fail the Bechdel test spectacularly) don't help much either. They glorify and build up the mythology of the anti-social white male nerd, further removing the domains of math and science and engineering from the fathomable futures of young women. To quote the authors of a study linking the mere presence of geek paraphernalia in a room to reduced female interest in computer science: "Environments can act like gatekeepers by preventing people who do not feel they fit into those environments from ever considering membership in the associated groups."[3]


So that's why it's hard to imagine getting 13 year old girls interested in computers: because, by 13, girls have already been socialized to not be interested in computers.


[1] Unlocking the Clubhouse, Jane Margolis and Allan Fisher, 2002.
[2] "No girls allowed", Tracey Lien, December 2, 2013.
[3] "Scientist = Geek Is A Dangerous Equation", Tania Lombrozo, October 21, 2013.

I hesitate to counsel definitively one way or the other, but my gut says you should stick with your computer science studies if you enjoy the subject matter. It's true that the social elements and feeling of belonging are important and I wouldn't dismiss those considerations out of hand, but I suspect that you'll be able to find your place and a network of friends with time and a little effort. And once you do, it'll be worth it.

I'm happily employed as a software engineer now and I'm so thankful for all the twists and turns that have taken me to where I am now -- it's a great career path, well-compensated, very flexible; the work is intellectually interesting, creative, collaborative, impactful and relevant to society.

But it was not clear to me that I wanted to be a software engineer until I actually took my first job as one, and even a year into that I was still doubtful of my choice. In college, I chose to not major in computer science because I was intimidated by my (mostly male) classmates and didn't feel like I belonged. (More on that here.) I eventually did a master's in CS, pressured by a good friend who knew better than I did what was good for me, but even after that I wasn't particularly committed to CS / software. Amongst other things, I applied to business schools for marketing PhD programs, and for industry roles that I was evaluating at that time, I was poking around at data analyst / data science positions and not engineering. I was finally convinced that I should give software engineering an earnest try, and so I did. But it wasn't easy, and I did feel lonely and out-of-place for a long time. (More on that here.) There were certainly a lot of heart-to-hearts with friends in and out of the industry, and many tears involved. I questioned many times whether I had the mental fortitude to be a female software engineer, and I questioned whether I could encourage younger women to go into the field when I myself could barely keep it together.

It got better when I found one close friend at work, another female software engineer, and I realized I wasn't alone. Some people reached out to me, and I reached out to some other people, and I found more kindred souls. It helped too that I got a lot more involved with the community, connecting with people on Twitter, meeting people 1:1, volunteering with mentorship programs, generally being present at events and meetups.

When I switched jobs, it was a natural reset and I made a conscious effort to invest in my social network outside of work. That was actually entirely sufficient for my mental health and happiness to have friends outside of work, but as the company grew and more people joined I also became good friends with a number of coworkers. If you just imagine that you'll jive with some percentage of the population that has similar interests and/or is compatible values- and personality-wise with you, and you increase the total number of people that you encounter or interact with, the number of people that you'll click with also increases.

You'll find friends, and it won't be so lonely :) Don't give up on something that you love and that is a great professional opportunity, too.

Just apply! You definitely don't need a CS undergraduate degree to get into a master's program in CS. I personally did EE for my undergrad and then did a master's in CS at Stanford; I also know at least three people that majored in other fields (mechanical engineering, statistics, economics) that are now in that program.

The 2013 Nike Women's (half-) Marathon was my first real* race so my views on it are perhaps tinged more positively for the excitement around that personal achievement -- but I really enjoyed it and was not put off by the stereotypical female trappings of the event. The overarching consideration and redeeming quality for me is that it gets people like me out there and running.

What was the draw of the NWM in particular? I have to admit the Tiffany's necklace was an easy selling point; I like pretty things and I would actually wear a Tiffany's necklace whereas most organization- or event-based paraphernalia typically comes in the form of very unstylish free t-shirts that are acceptable attire only as sleepwear. I certainly joked a number of times that I was doing the race for the necklace, but in truth that was just a quick, lighthearted answer that was easier to give than explaining that this felt like a good race to get started on because it's a big, well-organized event that's very accessible to new runners, and I felt almost-ready and anxious to do a "real race" but needed the security and support of (what the marketing literature refers to as) a tribe, even a tribe constructed by a capitalist institution to build their brand and promote materialism and consumerism.

As for the makeup wipes, chocolate, pedicures, etc., they were hardly a highlight of the race at all; just little extras along the way and at the end. Every race has different sponsors that try to target the demographic of the participants. It didn't feel so much like women need additional support to get through the race as that all these events are commercialized. Neither was the race particularly empowering, I felt, because while it's ostensibly celebrating women's athletic achievements, ultimately as a runner I just cared that I had 13.1 miles to cover and it was thrilling to be on the course and running.

That's very much not true. Most of our engineering team does not have frontend experience.

When I was making a similar decision in 2010, deciding between Facebook (~1500 employees, pre-IPO) and Quora (total company headcount of 4, pre-funding), these were the factors I considered:

1. learning opportunities (this was by far the most important point in my decision framework)

1a. in the technical realm

There is more structure around onboarding and engineering process at a larger company. For example, Google has an engEDU group which has tutorials and talks and other great resources for you to pick up new engineering knowledge; Facebook puts you through Bootcamp for your first six weeks, there are mobile development classes if you want to transition into that, etc.

However, in your main job you're likely to stay on a specific team for a while, focused on a very specific problem, where everything else has been abstracted away or otherwise taken care of for you already. You might go deep in that one problem, but you're less likely to see the full stack or range of engineering problems that the company is working on.

At a small company, you can (and may be forced to) bounce around projects, products, technologies, and teams a lot more, and you'll quickly acquire a breadth of knowledge that way. For example, in my 2 years at Pinterest I've worked on a re-architecture of our codebase; a database migration; memcache and redis caching abstractions; API endpoints and security; our email framework -- templates, logic, and infrastructure; feed quality and infrastructure; new user retention data analysis; performance debugging tools; our in-house web framework and rewrite of the website; the mobile website; amongst other things. Earlier this year I switched from backend to frontend work and got to pick up an entirely new set of skills. It's hard to imagine this amount of flexibility at a larger company.

As we build out the team we are starting to invest in onboarding materials and presentations so those are coming along nicely as well, but they won't be as fleshed out as Google's or Facebook's for a long while yet.

It's important that you know your own learning style and what you're looking to learn when you consider which opportunities are better for learning.

1b. learning about everything else / learning about startups

If you ever want to start your own company, joining a startup and absorbing all that's going on around you is one of the best things you can do to set yourself up for success. When teams are small, you're exposed to a lot more of the company; you'll see how to make product decisions and design processes for making product decisions, how to build and grow teams, how to work with customers, how to steer with data vs. intuition, how to evaluate fundraising opportunities and timelines, and so much more. These are all things you're unlikely to see very closely in a big company.

1c. mentorship

In terms of mentorship, the big companies can boast some famous people but they're not necessarily committed to the same projects and goals that you are, which means the mentorship may be less contextual and not as useful. Sheryl Sandberg offered to mentor me personally at Facebook but ultimately I figured that joining a smaller company where I was working directly with great people it would be a lot more meaningful of a learning opportunity. Pinterest has lots of really stellar folks that you will just be working side-by-side with; we have a relatively senior team in terms of work experience and there's a great culture of helping each other learn and grow.

1d. riding the rocket ship (this point wasn't applicable to me in 2010 when I was evaluating Quora, since it was so early stage, but I think it's applicable now for Pinterest)

Speaking of Sheryl, this quote of hers is a great one: "If you're offered a seat on a rocket ship, get on; don't ask what seat." Pinterest is poised for fast growth; we've already 20x'd our team headcount in about 2 years and we're still growing fast. We're just starting our monetization efforts and there will be a lot to do and build and learn as we not only make Pinterest a useful service for more and more people all around the world, but also turn it into a viable business. It'll be a fun ride.

2. building a network

One big point in favor of Google and Facebook is that they've amassed a lot of talented people on their campuses. Many of these people will move on to other companies and other great opportunities in the future and being connected to them will be very valuable.

The team at Pinterest is of extremely high caliber (germane to a comparison with Google and Facebook, many are ex-Google and ex-Facebook) and you'll get to know people much better, but the sheer number of people that you will add to your network from working at Pinterest is probably much smaller.

The people in your network may expose you to job opportunities, they may be your future co-founders, they may be good recruits to teams you're on later, they may be future clients or help facilitate introductions to clients, or they may simply share useful insights or be good friends.

3. financial returns

I like to think of the value of any potential options as 0 because I am conservative and don't like to be disappointed by unrealistically high expectations. (Compensation in terms of salary is pretty reasonable in any case: across the board pretty high, enough to live comfortably on and save some away, so even with equity being worth 0 you're in good shape.)

With that caveat, Pinterest has a lot of potential upside.

To contextualize with some numbers, in the latest round of funding investors put Pinterest's valuation at $3.8B; Google's market cap is $340B (October 2013). The comparison isn't totally nutty as there is a lot of commercial intent on Pinterest and a lot of demand amongst advertisers to capitalize on that intent. The reason why Google AdWords is so phenomenally successful is that search intent tends to be commercial and there's money there. So the hope is that that piece will work out similarly for Pinterest in display advertising, which nobody has really done well up to this point; but Pinterest is also a social site that people enjoy spending time on (as opposed to get in, get out with Google or Amazon) and use to discover content, so there's some secret sauce.

Obviously, the challenge for Pinterest is to execute on the potential.

4. work/life balance (I didn't consider this point much when I first graduated but now appreciate it deeply)

At all of these three companies -- Google, Facebook, and Pinterest -- you can work long hours, or you can set a very reasonable fixed schedule for yourself. It does depend on your team and your deadlines (I imagine Android to have more intense crunch times around big releases, for example; web software generally is on looser timelines for releases) but you can definitely find something that works for you.

At Pinterest, my hours are something like 9am to 6pm M-F, with occasional code reviews or emails after hours. There are people who are in the office for fewer hours, particularly those who have long commutes; there are people who are in the office for a lot more hours. I've settled on my current schedule because it's what works best for me given all the things I want to do outside of work; for example, I've picked up running and yoga in the past year and I run ~4 times a week and do yoga ~3 times a week. Being active keeps me healthy and happy, plus yoga is a moving meditation that helps me to reset; ensuring that I have life outside of work makes me more productive at work, too.

5. culture fit

You'll be spending more time with your coworkers than anybody else in your life, more than with your friends and possibly even more than with your significant other. Make sure you're ok with that. Definitely within larger companies like Google and Facebook and to some extent within Pinterest too, there's too much variance team by team to give any sort of useful commentary on the culture here; just make sure you have a good sense of what you're signing up for.


At Pinterest I think we really do have a crack at becoming the next Google or Facebook, and I think it's much more exciting to help build the next big thing than just to join the already big thing. But you can't really go wrong whatever you decide -- and this decision is highly reversible :)

Sonoma. Period.

Having just bought a vacation home in Sonoma (specifically the Agua Caliente neighborhood), I can strongly recommend looking there.  For similar reasons others mentioned, the main positives are:

Variety of travel options to/from
It typically takes less than 1 hour to get to Sonoma from the Golden Gate Bridge and is easily accessible from East Bay.  From Palo Alto, I get to my house in 1hr 40 min on average.  Plus, it's nice to stop in SF or Marin County on the way if I need to run errands or see friends.  Google Maps traffic helps me avoid tough spots on 101 or 280 and find a better alternative route.

Incredible value
I got a beautiful 3,000+ square foot modern home built only 5 years ago for the equivalent of what 1,500 sq ft average condo would cost in SF or really anywhere in the Peninsula.  Using Trulia as of 9/25/13, I compiled a look at $/square foot as one data point for comparison:
-Sonoma = $372
-Palo Alto = $1,000
-San Francisco = $727
-Berkeley = $505
-Carmel = $1,378
-Santa Cruz = $461
-Stinson Beach = $976

Peaceful getaway with urban conveniences
There are a number of vacationers up in Sonoma and it is still an agricultural economy (with some tourism) so the vibe is pretty peaceful.  You can see the stars at night and hear the crickets.  There are a few higher end hotels that offer spa services and you can find anything you need within a 10 minute drive of most anywhere.

Awesome food
Not only are there a lot of grocery stores in Sonoma proper (Whole Foods, Sonoma Market, Safeway, Lucky, mom & pop markets), there are also many award winning restaurants like Girl & the Fig, El Dorado Kitchen, and my favorite - El Molino.  Glen Ellen Star is incredible and quite close.  You are also 30-40 minutes from Bouchon, French Laundry, and other restaurant meccas.  Additionally, there are farmers markets going on in Sonoma or some town nearby every day of the week and the local produce is delicious.

Easily rentable/giftable
Summer and fall are very popular for weddings and harvest events in the area.  It would be quite easy to rent out your home or gift it to friends/family who have events in the area.

Fun for friends to visit
One of my main considerations in buying a vacation home was that I wanted to share it with friends and family.  I wanted to get a place somewhere that when I told a friend, they'd say, "Oh I'd LOVE to visit!"  This is why Sonoma topped Santa Cruz, Tahoe, Mill Valley, Carmel, and other places for me.  While they are nice places, my friends tend to visit those less frequently and have less enthusiasm to travel there.  Most everyone I know is excited to come to wine country for the weekend.

Enjoy!

Yes, it is possible to change functions.

One of our values at Quora is to continuously learn and adapt.  Not only do we do this as an organization, but also as individuals.

Coming to Quora, I changed functions.  As a manager at Quora and at Facebook, I've helped a number people change functions within tech and have developed some principles and points to consider related to this type of career progression:

1. Hold yourself to a high standard.  You are not a "shoo-in" just because you already know people at the company.
If you consider interviewing internally for another function, you should hold yourself accountable to do the same preparation as an external candidate.  This would likely mean hours of preparation studying the function and perhaps weeks or months developing the competency required.  Because you may know people in the function, it would be easy for people to assume that you got the role because you "know" people.  Given that, I always aim to leave no doubt that I would be more than qualified for the role and take the interviews very seriously.

2. The role and function should be essential to the company.
If you are interested in changing functions, you should first survey the greatest needs and gaps at the company and see if you potentially fit into one of those areas.  It's important to remember that the company needs should be your focus as that is where you'll have the greatest impact.  I've seen some people early in their career focus too much on going after the "sexy" team or title but lose sight of what's really critical for the company's success. 

3.  Work hard, execute efficiently, play well with others and people will approach you before you have time to start looking for a new function.
In my experience, people who dig in, work hard, roll up their sleeves, do the least glamorous work, and produce results will find other functions coming around trying to recruit them before they've even had time to start thinking about switching teams.  The best people who work hard and effectively with their team and across the company, are usually sought out for new roles.  When I see someone on my team humbly working hard and producing results, I want to retain them at the company as long as possible and so will often start early conversations about what could be next for them as I can imagine them having impact in a lot of areas because of their work ethic.  Conversely, if someone is not meeting expectations or showing poor work ethic, I'd be very reluctant to recommend they seek out other teams and would not give an internal endorsement.

Finally, as a rule of thumb, I think everyone should spend at least a year or more in their function before they make a major change.  It's only fair to contribute back to your team given the amount of time they invest in training and mentoring you at the beginning.  Given that, I discourage people from starting in any role at the company with the intention of it only being a "stepping stone" into something else.  You should pursue roles and functions that you are genuinely excited to learn and that allow you to focus on your overall impact to the team and the company.

I'm a bit older than people initially think when we meet. I didn't get an email address until I went to college in 1995.  Math had always been my favorite subject in school and I adored puzzles and games (still do).  That may be why I decided to create my own small personal website in 1997 using the University of Wisconsin's comp sci department servers. Sonoma. Period.

Having just bought a vacation home in Sonoma (specifically the Agua Caliente neighborhood), I can strongly recommend looking there.  For similar reasons others mentioned, the main positives are:

Variety of travel options to/from
It typically takes less than 1 hour to get to Sonoma from the Golden Gate Bridge and is easily accessible from East Bay.  From Palo Alto, I get to my house in 1hr 40 min on average.  Plus, it's nice to stop in SF or Marin County on the way if I need to run errands or see friends.  Google Maps traffic helps me avoid tough spots on 101 or 280 and find a better alternative route.

Incredible value
I got a beautiful 3,000+ square foot modern home built only 5 years ago for the equivalent of what 1,500 sq ft average condo would cost in SF or really anywhere in the Peninsula.  Using Trulia as of 9/25/13, I compiled a look at $/square foot as one data point for comparison:
-Sonoma = $372
-Palo Alto = $1,000
-San Francisco = $727
-Berkeley = $505
-Carmel = $1,378
-Santa Cruz = $461
-Stinson Beach = $976

Peaceful getaway with urban conveniences
There are a number of vacationers up in Sonoma and it is still an agricultural economy (with some tourism) so the vibe is pretty peaceful.  You can see the stars at night and hear the crickets.  There are a few higher end hotels that offer spa services and you can find anything you need within a 10 minute drive of most anywhere.

Awesome food
Not only are there a lot of grocery stores in Sonoma proper (Whole Foods, Sonoma Market, Safeway, Lucky, mom & pop markets), there are also many award winning restaurants like Girl & the Fig, El Dorado Kitchen, and my favorite - El Molino.  Glen Ellen Star is incredible and quite close.  You are also 30-40 minutes from Bouchon, French Laundry, and other restaurant meccas.  Additionally, there are farmers markets going on in Sonoma or some town nearby every day of the week and the local produce is delicious.

Easily rentable/giftable
Summer and fall are very popular for weddings and harvest events in the area.  It would be quite easy to rent out your home or gift it to friends/family who have events in the area.

Fun for friends to visit
One of my main considerations in buying a vacation home was that I wanted to share it with friends and family.  I wanted to get a place somewhere that when I told a friend, they'd say, "Oh I'd LOVE to visit!"  This is why Sonoma topped Santa Cruz, Tahoe, Mill Valley, Carmel, and other places for me.  While they are nice places, my friends tend to visit those less frequently and have less enthusiasm to travel there.  Most everyone I know is excited to come to wine country for the weekend.

Enjoy!

There are a number of strategies to pursue.  I'm going to outline a few ideas to consider when forming your starting strategy (not taking into account which placement order you get):

Number diversity strategy
Given there is a limit of 7 cards before you are at risk of losing half your cards, it can be advantageous to have a steady stream of resources coming into your hand throughout the game.  The best way to do this is to place your two first settlements on intersections with six different numbers total with ideally, the highest probability.  If you can manage it, the best numbers to be on from the beginning would be 4,5,6,8,9,10 or some combination as close to that as possible.  Ideally you would avoid being on a number twice and would expand such that your first settlement gains you two more numbers like 3 and 11 given the example above.

Cities first strategy
Since cities double your earning power, an effective strategy can be to optimize for as much wheat and rock as you can get early in the game, upgrade to two cities as quickly as possible, and then trade out some of your abundant wheat and rock for wood and brick later to build roads and expand.  If you can get access to sheep with this strategy, you can also quickly and easily pursue a strategy of buying a lot of development cards before building more settlements.

Corner scarce resources strategy
Depending on where the numbers land, it is always good to take a scan of which resources will be the most scarce in the game.  Brick and rock only have 3 tiles on the board whereas others have 4 so they are usually the best candidates.  However, if you see that wood only has one strong number and three very weak numbers, then you may want to corner out that strong number on wood, bolstering your trading power in the game.

Abundant resources port strategy
As a counter to the scarce resource strategy, you can also try to determine where there will be an abundance of resources based on which resource has the highest combined probability numbers and put one of your first two settlements on the trading port for that resource.  Opponents who aren't paying attention may trade you two sheep for a rock because they have an overage of sheep, forgetting that you are sitting on a sheep port and can now trade for any resource you need in your next turn.

Tip: Carefully consider initial road placement
Amateur players often think very little about which way to point their first roads.  You will quickly learn that pointing a road directly to a dead end or another opponent's settlement is very costly.  Make sure you point your road toward an area you want to expand that also is likely to be open after all the initial settlements have been laid.  I generally think it's a bad idea to "fight it out" for a settlement spot when two people have their roads pointed toward the same place.  If you lose that first battle, there's a very high chance you'll lose the whole game.  You should bluff and threaten to build in that direction but don't actually waste valuable cards on it unless you've got 80-90% confidence you can pull it off.

Have fun!

(Pic of my last game with my long-time Catan pals Lawrence Wong and Ari Gass, who I've found happen to hate the numbers diversity strategy and love the port strategy.)

Background: I grew up outside Milwaukee and went to the University of Wisconsin for undergrad.  Upon graduation, I worked briefly in Madison as an elementary music teacher.  In 2001, I moved to the Bay Area and looking back, I'm confident it was the smartest move I could have made (although I didn't know it at the time.)

Immediate differences you'll notice:

No seasons.  It took a couple years for me to get used to having no winter.  It's lovely to not have to shovel snow off your car but I remember thinking, "How do people know that time has passed here?  It's like one looooong year."

Housing is expensive.  In 2000 in Madison, I was paying $700/month for rent sharing a nice 2BR apartment.  My first 2BR in Oakland was $1250 and that was low for the area.  I'm sure even at that time that rent was double in SF ($2500).  I just purchased a home for ~$1M and never thought coming from the midwest that I'd ever do such a thing.

It's more acceptable to "flake" in CA.  I remember being shocked at how people would cancel meetings at the last minute.  Growing up in Wisconsin, cancelling in itself is a big deal but I would never dream to cancel anything less than a week in advance.  In CA, it's pretty common and acceptable for people to decide at the last minute not to attend a party or dinner they committed to attending.

People are smart and more worldly.  San Francisco and San Jose are always ranked in the top 10 most educated cities in the U.S. and you can feel it.  The average education level is just much higher here than in the rest of the U.S.  Also, most people are like you in that they came to the Bay Area for education or opportunity so it is a melting pot of people from all over the world....much more diverse than the midwest generally.

Extraordinary career opportunity. As for your career, I think moving to the Bay Area is the best move you could make for your field.  You could go into finance on the east coast but working in tech, especially on consumer web products, is thrilling.  I believe data science is getting as or more competitive than software engineering given the increasing amounts of data to crunch and testing required to be successful on web/mobile. 

Pack your bags and head out.  Just bring some extra rent money and leave your snow pants at home!
