I would argue that getting your degree at Wisconsin is one of the best decisions you could make to get the most of a college experience for the least cost.  I attended from 1995-2000 so surely things have changed but I'll outline some of the common themes that I think were there before I attended and persist today:

1. People are really nice.
You're in Wisconsin.  People are just nice there.  It's easy to make friends.  The dorms like Witte, Sellery, Chadbourne all hold upwards of 1,000 students so there's a huge concentration of students around to you meet and learn from.

2. Madison has the best of a big city at a much smaller size.
Just walk down State Street and you'll find a ton of shops, really good bars, restaurants, and even street performers.  Madison does very well from an entertainment standpoint as there is always something to do. 

3.  Parties, parties, and more parties.
I actually didn't drink much until I was 21 (somehow the campus police presos actually scared me) but there are plenty of house parties and bars.  Wisconsin has earned a reputation as #1 party school a number of years. Top Party Schools and Colleges for 2011, 2012 and 2013

4. Big 10 Football.
Camp Randall (UWBadgers.com - The Official Web Site of the Wisconsin Badgers - Facilities), built in 1917, holds over 80K fans.  Wisconsin has been in the Rose Bowl a number of times in the last 10 years and has traditionally had a very strong football team.  Additionally Ohio State, Northwestern, Michigan, and others in the Big 10 have great teams.  EVERYONE goes to the game.  It's a sea of red and the Wisconsin Marching Band is an institution, hosting their famous "5th Quarter". 

5. Stellar faculty.
Various departments are often ranked in the top 10 for public universities and often on par with Ivy League schools.  In particular, the education, communications, engineering, medical, law, and business schools are continually ranked among top programs.  Wisconsin is also a research university affording you the chance to do research as an undergrad (great preparation for grad school applications).

6. Politically exciting place to be.
Because Madison is the state capital, politics is always "in the air".  In addition, Wisconsin is a swing state so you'll find very opinionated Democrats and Republicans everywhere.  Political debate among Wisconsinites is common and respectful.

7. Beautiful outdoors.....but it gets cold.
The campus is situated between two lakes: Lake Mendota and Lake Menona.  Both offer fantastic lake shore trails for running and sailing in the summers.  Be prepared though to brave long, tough winters hiking up Bascom hill with sleet in your face and temperatures below zero.

8.  Memorial Union.
"The Union", Memorial Union, is an architecturally beauty that, when opened in 1928, the president of the university said, "The Union is a living room, which converts the University from a house of learning into a home of learning.?  It's a social center and the Rathskeller serves beer all year round including summers on the terrace when live bands play in front of the lakefront most nights.

9. Freedom to explore.
Because Wisconsin is such a big school, there are over 4,000 courses to choose from along with hundreds of clubs and extracurricular opportunities.  You will be able to find someone else interested in what you want to learn about or explore, even if it is a niche topic or activity. 

10.  100,000+ alums around the world.
Among the famous people who have attended Wisconsin are former Vice President Dick Cheney, renowned glass artist Dale Chihuly, author Joyce Carol Oates, aviator Charles Lindbergh, naturalist John Muir, and architect Frank Lloyd Wright.  Badger alums are super friendly and get together all over the world to watch football games and other athletic events.  When I moved to Austin, TX knowing no one, Wisconsin alums became some of my first friends!

Overall, I can't recommend Wisconsin enough.  It's an incredible experience.

(A fellow alum Erin Hubbard and me at the Rose Bowl in 2013. Go Badgers!)

This really depends on what you are selling.  For standard, secondhand things from the house, I would recommend actually taking your things and selling them at a flea market for one day.  For collectible items, selling online will likely get you the most profit.

Here are some advantages and disadvantages of each method:

Selling Online
Pros
More buyers overall
Higher likelihood of a match for a nitch collectables
Fun to post and watch an auction or sell via "Buy It Now" at a higher price

Cons
Shipping items is a lot of work, especially if the items are fragile
Shipping costs often make total price too high for regular items
Some buyers can claim item is of different condition than you described and refund/return process can be a pain
Creating listings with good pictures can take a lot of time

Actual Costs
Etsy charges $.20/listing plus 3.5% of the sale price (see Etsy - Help)
eBay charges 10% of the final price (see Standard selling fees)

Flea Market
Pros
Big market with other sellers means more foot traffic than a garage sale
No marketing costs
Usually have a Goodwill truck onsite so you can unload unsold wares at end of day

Cons
You don't set the date/hours and have to stay with your stand all day
Lots of haggling with customers

Actual Costs
Flea market fees vary widely from $10 - $100/day depending on the size and popularity.  Some allow you to sell once and some require multiple day commitments.  Some also require a state seller license.

Garage Sale
Pros
Convenient time/place/location as you set it!
Easy to add more stuff if you forgot something in your house

Cons
Hard to get foot traffic
"Early bird" requests, avid rummagers will call/write wanted first look before others

Actual Costs
Advertising on Craigslist or your local newspaper could cost $50-$100
Signs around the neighborhood cost $20-$30

Good luck!

If you've boiled down your decision to a shoot-out between Sproutcore or Cappuccino, I don't think you can go wrong with either one.

If you're trying to figure out the difference between the two, it's fairly simple: you write Cappuccino apps using Objective-J, an Objective-C-like syntax built on top of Javascript that's extremely similar to Objective-C. If you know Objective-C and Cocoa APIs already you'll feel right at home. So much so that it'll feel like you're literally writing a desktop Mac app or iPhone app.

Sproutcore, on the other hand, gives you the benefits of many design patterns in Cocoa but you're not writing a new language, you're still using Javascript and your code still looks like Javascript. A Javascript developer will need serious hand-holding and learning time to pick-up Cappuccino whereas they already know the language if they want to build a Sproutcore app.

Americans are great believers in the value of entrepreneurs and small business. That faith underlies the JOBS (Jumpstart Our Business Startups) Act, a new law that will make it easier for small companies to raise money and bypass the regulatory ?friction? that firms encounter when they go public. The law assumes that people who can't find jobs may be able to find investors instead, and that small companies will be able to get the financing they need to grow bigger and hire more people. Angel investors, friends, and family will boldly go where banks may fear to tread.
 
The JOBS Act is an extreme example of Americans? belief in people?s essential goodness, and everyone?s right to self-fulfillment. Every entrepreneur should be entitled to raise funding from willing investors. It is a uniquely American approach, and capitalistic in the best sense of the word, for it encourages (and democratizes) investment, rather than fueling consumption.
 
Small (under $1 billion) companies can raise money directly from small investors in a formalization of the ?crowdfunding? approach, whereby a project?s principals post their plans on a Website and ask for money, essentially opening up the initial public offering (IPO) market. The theory underlying the law is that there will be a new set of accredited third-party marketplaces, rather than the overburdened Securities and Exchange Commission (which missed Bernie Madoff's monster Ponzi scheme), will ensure that entrepreneurs tell the truth and that investors know what they are buying.  (Of course, that begs the question of how thoroughly vetted and reliable those third-party marketplaces andtheir vetting systems will be.)
 
While this initiative was born in the United States, many countries are wondering how to jumpstart their own entrepreneurial sectors, and may be tempted to follow America?s lead. So why do I hope that they resist that temptation?
 
Unfortunately, the JOBS Act is as likely to be successful as the US government's earlier attempts to ensure that  American families could buy their own homes. Low down payments, deferred interest, and other enticements made it attractive for people to buy their own homes (or to speculate with second homes) whether they could afford to or not.
 
Mortgage brokers were happy to get in on the act. Some were driven by an honest mission to expand property ownership; others were driven by greed. Some knew that the people to whom they were selling houses could not afford it; others simply did not want to know. Some played by the rules; others forged documents. The banks that originated mortgage loans sold their portfolios to investors who didn't really understand what they were buying. 
 
In the same way, the JOBS Act will ease life for some deserving people ? and most likely attract many more who are less deserving. The new system will attract scam artists and promoters who will encourage unsuitable companies to seek investment and oversell the companies to individuals who can't afford to lose the money that they invest.
 
I wish I had more faith in the system, but the problem is not a lack of good people, good investors, or good entrepreneurs. The problem is that, without regulation, bad people take advantage of the good ones. While regulation and restrictions may hamper small business, not all regulation and restrictions are useless.
 
Yes, there are some wonderful, honest companies that deserve investment and can?t get it, but they are not that common. I see a lot of start-ups. Many are appealing and have good ideas, yet most of them fail. Now the  quality even of the honest start-ups is likely to decline as there are more of them, and they will spend more of other people?s money before failing.
 
For example, with more start-ups, it will be even harder for each of them to find  management talent and the right employees. Indeed, many people whom an entrepreneur might have hired will probably become the CEOs of competing start-ups. Meanwhile, all of them will be competing for a finite number of customers, and those companies that make progress will then have to compete for scarcer scale-up capital.
 
Many investors in these startups are likely to lose their money. Even under the current system, many angel investors lose money. The best route to success in angel investing is to invest in, say, ten or more separate companies, so that you have the chance of at least one big winner. But again, a broader investor pool is likely to reduce the average number of investments per investor, with inadequate diversification leading to many more losers than winners.
 
The faith that drives the JOBS Act is the same magical thinking that drives many Internet phenomena: People are good and everyone means well. But the Internet?s easy accessibility and low entry barriers have led to spam and malware and bad behavior; each new service starts out ?clean,? but then ends up requiring its own regulations.
 
Just ask eBay, Google, or Facebook how much they spend on security, fraud detection, and the like. They don?t want to tell you, which says a lot. As on the Internet, so in real life: sometimes friction has a purpose.

+1 to everything above... but beyond that, great conferences have a purpose beyond entertainment. If you leave the same as you came, that purpose was not fulfilled.  Each person gets their own particular benefit (and fulfills their own purpose), but in the end, the conference has to *do* something - outline a new industry (or at least a trend), galvanize people to create or fix something, announce something, whatever.  Conferences need an MC (or a pair) that have some vision... (Most hired MCs don't qualify, IMHO.) A great conference, like a play or any other performance, needs rhythm and flow - but it's closer to jazz than than to opera.  The excitement is in spontaneity:  The organizers need to have that purpose, but if they know *exactly* what they want, what's the point of the conference?


As for little things - fewer slides, more audience* participation (with a well-lighted room so people can see one another), badges big enough to read, enough places to sit for smaller conversations, etc.  (*yes, I know, even the concept of "audience" is passe.)

And another trick:  Put the conference somewhere remote (but conveniently near an airport), so that the "important" people come and stay, rather than pop in to address the audience and leave.  Make the speakers stick around and mingle... 

Beyond that, match the format to the purpose.  Sponsor/no sponsors, small/big, mostly "un"/highly structured.... all work if they fit the purpose.

personally, I love new, small conferences around new topics where people can find one another and create a new market - e.g. the recent Quantified Self conference in Mountain View.  On the other hand, I love AllThingsD and was really bummed I had to miss it this year  (because of an immovable board meeting).

Also, a short plug for www.lanyrd.com, a great Twitter-based tool to enrich conferences (and provide context around speakers).

The following are my personal observations about what Fab did right as I've studied their success.

Understanding the Customer - The Vitra Eames Elephant Giveaway
Fab knew exactly the type of customer they wanted to go after and understood from that persona the things that would resonate with them and catch their attention. Prior to launch Fab ran a sweepstakes giving away eight Vitra Eames Elephants[2]. These elephants are expensive, somewhat of a collectors item, and are made by a powerful design brand, Vitra. Additionally they were originally designed by Charles & Ray Eames, two legends of modern design.
The sweepstakes was built to be viral, with users receiving additional entries for each friend they referred who entered the sweepstakes.

This promotion went like wildfire but it was based on understanding the core customer and identifying what would resonate with that customer. Giving away something coveted by the design-minded, and pegging themselves to a brand like Vitra and the Eames legacy, let people in their target audience know that they knew what they were doing.

Understanding Viral Marketing
In addition to the brilliant Vitra Eames giveaway with it's incentives to refer friends, Fab had a gamified pre-launch page which encouraged people to refer friends to move up the invite list for early access. They coupled this powerful status mechanic, with the ability to earn additional credits once the site launched.

You may say many people do this, but what is special about Fab's case is that they really understood the motivators that drove their audience to act. Gabe Zichermann often references the main motivations when it comes to users taking action. In order of importance, those are:
Status
Access
Power
Stuff

Most referral programs simply start at "stuff" (AKA money) by giving people $10 when they refer a friend who joins. Fab understood that in the hierarchy of motivations "Stuff" is actually at the bottom. So they built the page to give people who invited more people in "Status" by making high referrers "Founding Members" and "Access" by promising those that referred the most early access ahead of the general public. They made sure to tie in the "Stuff" with credit incentives, but they got the other pieces of the puzzle right to drive that referral loop.

Product Building Community
They made a couple of key decisions when it came to pre-launch product.

1. They built their own viral landing page. Many companies use LaunchRock or other viral pages, but Fab built it's own to provide the custom gamifications mentioned above. They're subtle but important differences between Fab's pre-launch experience and the standard LaunchRock one.

2. They built a product discovery and sharing inspiration board where people could add their favorite design finds from around the Web. This was before they were even selling anything. But it let them do a couple of things:

a. Get people engaged with the site and build community around great deisgn.
b. Develop a list of products and designers that were important to their potential customers and a great list of leads to run down for early product sales.
c. Create brand awareness and repeat visits prior to launch/commerce.
d. Create a curated experience that pointed to what Fab was going to become and gave people credit for adding unique things (it was almost like a pre-cursor to Pinterest.)

This gave them a bunch of regular users before they even started selling stuff.

Smart PR
Jason and his team are great storytellers. Jason blogs regularly at BetaShop[3] and loves interacting with users, influencers and bloggers. Fab drove a ton of traffic from PR during it's initial launch, which resulted from their team's ability to tell a compelling story.

Disrupting the Market with a Great Product
Last, but certainly not least, Fab disrupted a very fragmented market by pulling together a collection of design finds that was easy to browse and buy, with a discount to boot. Shopping modern design prior to Fab was exceptionally hard. Small boutiques with terrible websites, bad customer service policies and prices that were all basically governed by the designers and MAP pricing.

Fab turned all of that on its head with a superior product that made design accessible to more shoppers, removed inefficiencies from modern design furniture ecommerce, and unlocked the latent demand in the marketplace because of it.

Post-Launch Success
Following the big launch I believe Fab has done several things exceptionally well to drive them to become a premier ecommerce player:

Email marketing - they are very aggressive email marketers, but have provided detailed controls that keep most people subscribed even with the large volume of email.

Continual referral programs - they are smart about dropping in limited time bonuses and incentives to drive referrals to the site.

Product innovation - they continue to innovate and add compelling elements to their product.

Analytics/Data - Jason and team use both RJ Metrics and Custora to better understand their customer and experiences to drive their business.

Shifting of Value Proposition/Brand Positioning - They've moved away from daily deals to more of an Amazon model with a ton of SKUs across dozens and dozens of categories.

Listening to Customers - They do a great job of surveying and learning from customers.

Segmentation - They're segmentation (as seen from their email practices) is top notch and allows them to engage with customers in a relevant and meaningful way.

If you think of Google+ as a destination, then you could be forgiven for thinking it isn't as lively as other social outposts. However to think of G+ in that way is to not comprehend what it actually is.

Google+ isn't a place, it's a new layer on the Google stack. It permeates and aggregates everything. It personalizes and ties your activities back across every platform, finally giving Google a holistic view of a person's activity online.

Google+ is also in very early days. While the integrations they've completed to-date are impressive, there are so many more to really bring the vision to life.

Facebook started out wanting to be the social plumbing of the Web. That changed when they needed to ramp revenue. Google is building the true social fabric of the Web, and it will be indistinguishable from their products over time.

Whether your friends are actually at Google+ at the moment is irrelevant. It's the aggregate interactions and new layer that is the real network, and that is growing and thriving and isn't going anywhere for a long time to come.

Audible uses credits because it fits their primary customer relationship model best. Audible primarily sells subscriptions marketed, roughly, as "get 1 book a month" or "get 2 books a month" for a monthly fee. By using credits members are able to pick any book on Audible with one credit. It makes the positioning and marketing of the membership plan much simpler to explain and understand. That way for members they never have to worry about if they have $15/month for books and one costs $27/etc.

When you have a subscription service like Audible's a digital good like an audio book file, you can leverage the economies of low marginal costs and basically come up with a formula that let's you calculate how many books you can offer per month, at how much $$ per month, and be profitable.

So it works both for the consumer - easier to understand in a subscription model, and for Audible, makes it easy to model customer LTV and profitability by using an average across all customers.

They shouldn't.

They aren't going after Reddit karma, they shouldn't go after Quora PeopleRank. There are just some ecosystems that aren't a fit for some products. I think Quora and Reddit are both two good examples of bad fit for both the communities and Klout.

A few ideas:

Offer to volunteer. This doesn't work for every conference, but many have volunteers that help paid staff with things like check in, badge check duties, running mics, etc. in exchange for working a day or so as a volunteer you'll often get a free badge to enjoy the rest of the conference.

Offer to be a conference live blogger or tweeter. Many conferences have live blogging and/or tweeting of sessions. They need people to cover these sessions. Offer to help in exchange for a free badge.

Submit a panel idea or speaking session. While not feasible for things like AllThingsD, you can hone a pitch and put together a panel that can get you in as a speaker or panel participant. All of these people obviously get in free.

Lobby Con the event. Troll the lobbies of the event and unofficial after parties. Most of the networking happens in the halls anyway. People leaving the conference early (for good) may give you their badge on their way out, gaining you access to the rest of the show.

Enter contests to win free badges. Many times conferences will give away a few badges. Pay attention to when those are and enter early and often.

Submit a press request. If you blog regularly on the subject you may qualify for a press badge or blogger discount. Many people try to abuse this and so conference organizers vet these carefully. Make sure if you try it you actually have a reasonable belief that you qualify.

Get sponsored. Many companies send influencers to events in exchange for spreading the word about a particular company. If you have a large following you can reach out to companies and pitch them a sponsorship. You should know what you're doing here, and actually have a worthwhile following before attempting this.

Offer to volunteer for an exhibitor. Same idea as the volunteer idea above, but this time help work the booth for a sponsoring company. You'll get a badge and can cruise around while not working the booth.

Get an exhibit hall only badge. These are usually really inexpensive and can get you in the lobby for great networking.

Square isn't competing on transaction fees. That's just a race to the bottom, and bigger companies with diverse revenue streams and deeper pockets are the only ones who will win that game. Square is playing two games: frictionless value exchange and business intelligence for small business.

As we've seen, most payment companies don't know what the word frictionless means, and as long as Square keeps innovating they'll stay ahead of the fast followers. They also have better engineering and tech talent that can develop elegant solutions to delivering real business intelligence to small businesses in a way that's never been imagined.

They'll be competitive on fees, but won't ever position themselves as the cheapest. They'll be the easiest to use, have an exceptional brand, and deliver tons of value in ways that major carriers will only be able to poorly copy 18 months after Square is on to the next innovation.

Google assumes people are rational and that products should be utilitarian and functional.  "Users" (i.e. people) are emotional, however, and most social products thrive by satisfying psychological drives (often alluded to as the Seven Deadly Sins).  For example, even for a product like LinkedIn a core driver of a huge fraction of usage is vanity.  (Back in my day, 36% of all clicks from the home page were users viewing their own profile.)

To understand why Google fails at social products ask, for example, your favorite Google engineer or product manager why the NFL is so popular.  They are dumbfounded; the NFL has no utility, yet accounts for a huge fraction of a normal Americans' time and disposable income.  If you can't explain football's impact, it is nearly impossible to build a mainstream social product except by brute force.

Why I am joining Khosla Ventures

I moved to Silicon Valley in 2000, joining a bunch of misfits who had some provocative ideas about how the world should work. Find paying customers before you start your business.

Offer your product to people who you think will want it (i.e. your target customer) and see if they will pay for it in advance.

Almost every business idea is guaranteed not to work out the first try. That?s why you have to Validate, Validate, Validate.

If you cannot find paying customers for your service/product/idea you have a problem, BUT you have also been given the greatest chance to learn why the person is NOT buying and what they WILL buy.

I?ve started a number of my own companies and also worked at a few startups (Facebook, Mint) that have since hit it big. My current business AppSumo was validated and built for $50. Before AppSumo, the #1 problem I found at my last business was getting customers, and it drove me crazy.

The solution? I had to go out and make sure that people actually wanted what I was offering. So I started finding web apps that I knew people were using and then tried to see if I could sell the premium version of that apps to people. The first way I validated was by offering an imgur Pro account at a special price on Reddit to Redditors. (Read How AppSumo was built for $50 for details.)

Keep in mind you do not actually need to have the product in hand or have the service set up...yet. The promise of the product is enough. Recently I started selling taco shirts, but only after my original idea failed. (How You Can Accidentally Start Your Own Company -- It?s a quick story about how to validate without spending $$.)

If potential customers don?t like your idea OR even if they like the idea but won?t pay... you know you have to find out what they will buy.

Before you start your business, and before write up a business plan, and before you start making a website, and before you print business cards, and before you create a logo, AND before you quit your day job.....

VALIDATE.


Most people start a business backwards. They do everything else before they do the most essential thing: Finding paying customers.

Once you know this and internalize it, you will see ?wantreprenuers? everywhere who have ideas, plans, and schemes?but no paying customers.

When we started Monthly1K course (How To Make a $1,000 a Month Business by AppSumo) the entire purpose was to change this problem and help the average person see/take actionable steps towards finding a profitable idea without wasting time and money.

Depending on your business/business idea, there are different ways to find your first customers. One of the best ways to come up with ideas for how to validate is to read how others found their first customers (see How I Got My First 3 Customers). In many cases they did research, found the customers' pain points, or figured out how to offer a better version of an existing service.

Bottom Line: Get paying customers before you do anything else.

Very Basic Examples of Validation:

Starting a Restaurant: Sell what you think will be your top plates at a dinner party. Ask people to send you $20 by PayPal in advance?before you buy the ingredients. Sell 20+ plates in advance.

Starting a Service: Look through Craiglist, forums, or Quora to find people who need what you?re offering. Email them, call them, tweet them and offer your services but make them pay first (discount a little if you have to).

Selling a Product: Send an email to friends and family about the product, what it will do, how it will solve their problems and ask them to PayPal you $15 - $45 in advance. If you are solving a real problem or fulfilling a need, they will pay.

Every business gets its first clients differently. The challenge for many entrepreneurs is to get their first three customers.

Before diving into my answer, it?s important to get your first clients BEFORE you start your business.

Traditional answers start by telling you to build a website, print business cards, and take out ads. Many of the most successful businesses take an approach that allows them to validate (see whether or not people will pay you) their business, their ideas, and value proposition before jumping in with both feet. When they validate (find their first three paying clients) or fail at validating they either strengthen their original idea OR they are able to find a new business/idea without wasting time, money, social capital.

When we started the website How I Got My First 3 Customers (more than 60 entrepreneurs tell their stories) we found that the way people get their first clients is as different as the founders and businesses themselves. There are too many stories to write up, but here is an overview (check out the full website for all of the stories).

For some bloggers, their first readers were family members and coworkers. Some new business got a lucky break from a local newspaper that decided to cover the business. Although many slugged it out by going door to door to offer free estimates, others spun their 9to5 skills and industry knowledge into a side project leveraging free work for testimonials and referrals.

A few basic ideas on how to get your first clients:
Visited 250 houses in 6 hours. Result: 11 leads and closed 5 clients.
Started visiting forums, going to meet ups, interviewing people. Result: Built an app that addressed customers need and then scaled to grow the business.
Reach out to those really close to you and willing to help. Result: One major client came through a friend of a friend.
Search for people disliking competitor products by looking at people follow or like competitors on Facebook. Result: You have a potential client looking for something better from the start.
Interview potential customers to design the service/product to them. Result: These interviewees often turn into clients.
Some advice from these entrepreneurs:
Don't underestimate forums. We Googled "kpop forums" and reached out to fans from there.
Do what you are good at. Go after it. Do it cheap and don't spend money before you make money.
Business starts and thrives on word of mouth, referrals, and product research.
Build relationships with key influencers and potential 'referral partners' who are connected within your target customer's circles, and offer to help them, do great work, even do it for FREE.
Keep trying every method possible then stop and keep doing what works.

As Oliver Emberton wrote earlier, it is one challenge to get your first clients and it is another challenge to get your first paying clients. When you are able to offer some value up front (show them something new, solve a small part of their problem, or introduce them to a new software) and whet their appetite. IF you are able to solve REAL problems for people you will be able to get clients. If you are great at solving real problems (and enjoyable to work with) you will be able to get many more clients! (A lot of people feel guilty charging for their time or service starting out [see How Not to Feel Guilty about Charging For Your Time.] Remember you are helping to make money for your customers and clients.)

I?ve helped hundreds of businesses validate and launch successfully. In the past year, we launched "How To Make a $1,000 a Month Business." It?s an interactive (action-focused) course that shows you a ton of real business validations and how their initial ideas, using these same techniques, turned into profitable businesses.

Just to preface, I've had some success with starting 2 businesses (1 7-figure and 1 8-figure) along with spending over $150,000 in cash and 1.5 years of time with businesses that have failed.

Currently I'm helping over 1,000 people start their own businesses with How To Make Your First Dollar.

Okay, now that we have some credibility out of the way, let's get it on.

Let me resolve some common excuses people make about starting a business:

1- You NEED a co-founder. That's an excuse that you don't have the skills yourself, you do. It's 100% more easy to convince someone to join once you get traction.

2- YOU NEED funding. Do you really? If you analyze the core problem you are actually solving you'll realize you can do that in more ghetto ways. I'll show you a few more below. Get out of Silicon Valley!

3- You HAVEN'T thought of the golden idea. This is a huge common thing which allows you to excuse yourself from ever starting. Same with people who have too many ideas but not enough start.

Okay, now that you have excuses out of the way you have to break-through your fear of failure.


                                      Take the hi-5 challenge.

Most people struggle with this or immediate think it's childish. I have been MIND BLOWN the impact facing fear and rejection has for people while they go through our "Failure Olympics." Once you go through it, you understand.

So go try and hi-5 one random person on the street. Yea, it's awkward. Yea, it's hard. But once you do it and realize it's not that bad, you get to move on!

Okay to figure out your idea.

The easiest thing is next time you go to a restaurant or business or friend who even has more than $1 (99% of the people you should surround yourself with do).

Ask them this, verbatim:

I'm taking a course about starting a business and they forced me to ask you 2 questions. You cool with that? (they'll say yes and you joke how you just used one of the questions)

Then you ask, what are the top 3 things you are facing today that you'd LOVE someone to solve.

At this point they are going to say some generic and MAYBE something very specific.

Now you have a TON of business ideas. Surprise!

Okay, my PERSONAL preference is for you to really solve something that YOU want to see created in the world. It'll be way more fun than solving things for others. Also, you don't have to do market research since you ALREADY know what sucks.

Example of this could be: dang, there's no X type of restaurant in town, man it's really hard to find a good massage person or where should I eat tonight.

WARNING: DO NOT start coding. YOU don't need any code to get your business going. Limitations will help your creativity.

Now it's time for validation. Do people ACTUALLY want what I'm trying to sell.

Validation is seeing where on the "totem pole" of what you're offering is to the customer.

      This is an example totem pole of things I enjoy.

Simply, how important is it for the other person to exchange their time ("money") for the service / product ("value") you are offering.

For example, high on my totem pole are quality tacos but low is paying someone to tie my shoe laces.

I'll simplify Validation (really knowing that people want what you are offering) into 2 themes:

1- Pay me. This is NOT vaporware, this is the clearest signal someone wants what you are offering. Say you want to start a SaaS biz that helps people run their Google ads. How can you get 2 confirmed customers ahead of building the product. It'll only get harder to get customers if you can't even find 2.

Note: YOU SHOULD do the work manually instead of trying to code. DON'T fall into that trap.

Also, people will promise anything, "of course I'd use that." How about you ask me if I'll give you a $1,000,000? Do it.

Noah says, "SUREEEEEE."

Now try to collect that money.

Exactly.


Money is the clearest signal someone wants what you are offering.

2- Free with intent to commit. This can be getting people on a mailing list and seeing if they open. Ie. you want to start a blog / magazine regarding yoga for dudes. See if you can get 10 people within 48 hours to join.

Another validation, say you want to be a marketplace for dog sitting. How can you connect 1 dog owner with a sitter. No domain names, no coding, no biz-partner, just real validation.

Validation is completed IF within 48 hours you can get 3 paying customers or 10 intented people.

If no one wants it, GREAT. You saved TIME and MONEY, now you can find out what's higher on the person's totem pole.

If they want it, then you can proceed to marketing time.

Warning: If marketing and growth is hard it's cause your product is NOT validated.


Marketing time

1. Set a 30 day objective. Imagine driving your car without knowing your final destination. Once you know exactly where you want to go, it's way easier to plan the best route to get there. I highly recommend you using my Quant Based Marketing for Start Ups. It's what helped Mint.com sell for $170 Million.

2. Limit your budget. Advertising is an easy excuse why the business it not working.

3. Do more of what you did during your validation phase.

4. Read this article: Noah Kagan's answer to Marketing: What are key strategies to acquire first 100K users with zero marketing budget?

Kick ass on your business and have fun!


Bonus time

Accountability is huge. With How To Make Your First Dollar, we didn't have it at first but added check-ins and a support group. Shocking the impact people have with that support system when times are tough or good.

These tips are coming from a recovering let's have coffee person.

Here are my strategies in an effort to block 100% of coffee grabs:
Similar to X, I request clarification or questions via email. Literally, 85% of meetings go to this level and then stop.
If the person persists, I suggest we chat in real-time to talk via Skype. This kills off another 10% of the meetings.
Lastly, I'll push it to a phone call while I'm on the bus or driving.
For the remaining 5%:

a) If the person comes from a friend or respected person (both of these are hard to turn down), I suggest they join me for lunch in my area and let them know ahead of time it's for 30 minutes.

Note: Use http://tungle.me and only allow meeting blocks of 15 or 30 minutes. It's convenient because it can sync with Google Calendar.

b) I have a no-meetings-on-Monday-and-Friday policy that I tell people about.

Update: Recently I've been experimenting with group meetings which work really well. You just group together the people that want to meet, helps reduce awkward conversations, might connect two other people and reduces total # of meetings you have.

Bonus: You can try using an auto-responder tactic to all emails but I find this approach weird.

Once you start rejecting, you feel ownership of your time and people will respect your time before they contact you. Seth Godin will respond to your email generally in the same day. However, since he rejects all meetings and you "assume" he's busy, you are more considerate about emailing requests for his time.

Great question. Actually, I don't attend any Demo Days. I don't believe in Demo Days. I think they are a showcase of who is the best at on-stage presentations and who is the best coached & polished. It's why at Launchpad LA we don't do Demo Days.

I prefer to come before the Demo Day. I prefer 1-on-1 interaction. I like to get to know the companies, their issues, their struggles, their plans. Demo Day doesn't tell you any of that.

I'm not saying Demo Days have zero value. They teach companies to present their ideas cogently and in front of a crowd. But mostly they produce too much hype, too little value.

I should add then when I do attend events like TechCrunch Disrupt it's normally when I'm invited to speak or (gulp) sit on a panel. And I spend most of my time in the corridors talking with entrepreneurs & investors. My ADD is too strong to sit through a bunch of pitches.

Thanks for asking.

Often VC's tell you "keep in touch" as a polite way of saying, "no." The reason they do this is that there's very limited incentive to say "no" outright because if you do catch a fire they don't want to have shot themselves in the foot.

My recommendation is to stay in touch with VCs whom you respect even after they say "no" and you will see the level of engagement they have with you.
- Do they return emails?
- Are they willing to help? (I'm surprised more entrepreneurs don't realize that VCs love to help - even when they haven't invested. Every VC you meet ought to be part of your network since they tend to know many people
- Are they willing to have occasional 15-minute phone calls?
- Will they meet periodically for coffee / updates on the business?

Most VCs WILL say "no" the first time. Not because they're jerks but because VC math is simple. In most larger funds each partner will do 2 deals per year. That equals a lot of "no's."

Hands down, the most impressive analysis to do on backlinks is using paid software to go out and crawl every single link a website has. Then you take those links and pull in all of the anchor text data. After that you organize that list by PageRank. While everyone will whine about how PageRank doesn't matter anymore it is absolutely a powerful gauge at a glance as to how powerful a website and backlink is. This will give you a better understanding of your competitors (or yourself) and how strategic, funded and intelligent their backlink / SEO campaigns are. You will also be able to detect "trends" inside of their linking strategy. To do all of these operations in one swoop, purchase Market Samurai and use the SEO Competition / Anchor Text analysis tool then obtain pagerank data and sort it. You will be smarter and better than all those people using inferior tools like Site Explorer and Majestic SEO.

I do use Majestic SEO as a first line of defense to see what is gong on with a campaign in terms of visual volume and progression for a website.

First of all, don't use Adsense for tracking traffic. Put Google Analytics on the site for tracking traffic and also ad StatCounter on your site for more real time analytics, keyword and referral information.

I use Adsense channels not for tracking a specific website but more specifically a specific placement of the Ad Unit. For instant, SiteNameRightSkyscraper SiteNameBottomPost. When you create the channel, name it with an identifier to the site and the location.

Next click on AdSense setup, Select Your Ad Unit, Size, Assign the Colors, now select your new specific channel and place that code exactly where you identified it to be in your site. You will track impressions on your ad and clicks but don't rely on this for traffic analysis.

It was highly inappropriate and probably illegal.  If I were them I'd explore filing suit against her for "false light" invasion of privacy at a minimum, perhaps other privacy and defamation claims as well.

The two aspects eliciting tremendous backlash are (1) plain hypersensitivity to an overheard conversation not intended for her, and (2) extreme overreaction involving multiple steps taken, knowingly and intentionally, to inflict public damage on private individuals ? whether as retribution, for her own self-aggrandizement, or other reasons.

In general, we are not entitled to ambush an ordinary person on private property, photograph them up close without their consent, broadcast those photos to thousands of members of the general public while claiming on a pure hearsay basis that the people pictured are guilty of misconduct.  Ironically, Richards used (abused) her own privilege to publicly shame two previously unknown people to make a point about privilege.  A much safer way to report this kind of thing while seeking maximum publicity would be to go to the press, giving them the photos and telling the story.  Decent journalists would research it, look to verify facts and seek comment, etc. before running the story.

Saying off-color things to each other, not intending to be overheard is not harassment. We are all subjected to tastless jokes and other offensive remarks our entire lives.  How many times have you overheard a racist joke?  Believe it or not, plenty of women actually find dick jokes to be funny (at least some of the time).  Like, I dunno, my wife (who's done improv comedy) or pretty much every comedienne alive.  Have you listened to Sarah Silverman?  Watched Sex and the City (TV series & creative franchise)?  How on earth could something involving "dongles" be so offensive as to constitute harassment if unintentionally overheard?  In fact, isn't it patronizing to assume in this day and age that all women are such delicate flowers that their tender ears need to be sheltered from profanity or coarse humor?  (Importantly, if there were things like threats of violence involved, mention of rape, etc., I will eagerly eat my words.  I haven't read anything to that effect.)  The term "pedestalism" comes to mind ? see Frontiero v. Richardson.

This is noise to be tuned out, or boorish behavior to be reported to the conference organizers in keeping with event policy.  It would be harassment if it were aimed at her, which by all accounts it was not ? or if these yahoos persisted after Richards made it clear she could overhear and found their remarks unwelcome.  Without those things, it lacks the necessary element of intent.  Clearly nobody intended to hurt, harm, intimidate or harass her.  By contrast, everything about Richards' conduct was deliberate, intended to cause as much harm and/or milk as much publicity as she could from that single event.

I agree with the general sentiment expressed by others:  Probably not if it's a California corporation and most or all investors are based in California; otherwise, it could present a (generally surmountable) challenge to closing a financing round.

California is home to the largest concentration of startups and VCs in the U.S.  It also spawned the odd creature known as the quasi-California corporation.  State law provides that regardless of where a company is incorporated, it will be treated as if it were a California corporation for purposes of certain key governance requirements if the company's center of gravity is in California and a majority of its shares are held by Californians.  For startups based here, that effectively undermines some of the benefits of incorporating in Delaware or other company-friendly jurisdictions.  (Without going down that rathole, recent court decisions have called this law's enforceability into question.)

In VC-sized deals ($1MM+), it will always be worth the expense and hassle to reincorporate in Delaware simply to close the investment.  At the opposite extreme, if an angel offers $20,000 but wants to invest in a Delaware corporation, it may not be worth it.  In that sense, it could make a difference at the margin, which is one reason I generally favor Delaware from inception.

The question asks about investors in general, not limited to Venture Capital or typical Angel Investors.  Anecdotally, I've seen non-traditional investors increasingly involved in financing early stage ventures.  If the lead (or only) investor is located somewhere else, it could be happy with its own home state as the corporation's domicile, as it undoubtedly has legal, accounting and other experts in that state.  (Think of a Texas billionaire investing in a Texas corporation as one example.)  International investors often find it beneficial for tax reasons to invest in a Cayman Islands or other offshore entity.

No.  Ignoring technical issues (does the data even still exist?) and looking only at the legal side, the analysis depends on who's seeking the posts and in what context.  It can get complicated in a hurry, but the basic rule in the U.S. is that contents of electronic communications (as opposed to metadata like time/date stamps) can only be produced to government agencies with a search warrant, and only to private parties (everyone else) with the consent of the subject.

Posts, like email messages, are considered content.  Government entities can subpoena the most basic user information (email address, etc.) but need a court order for more detailed metadata and a warrant (issued by a judge upon finding probable cause) for access to the contents.  It's analogous to police looking at the outside of an envelope with address and postmark, etc., vs. opening and reading it.  The law in question is the Stored Communications Act, a part of the Electronic Communication Privacy Act (ECPA).

Private parties in litigation can subpoena user data / metadata but not content.  ECPA is strict on that point.  If you think about it, this actually makes sense:  If you're litigating a dispute with someone, the court expects you to subpoena the other person to produce copies of messages herself (either by just handing it over or by voluntarily requesting her own records from the service provider and then delivering them) ? or not:  These things are fought over in litigation.

Bottom line:  Even if the data exists, law enforcement needs a warrant, and everyone else can't get from the service provider at all.

Because the relevant stock exchange rules don't require it.  At the risk of sounding flip, a billion dollars ? in cash and/or stock ? isn't that much money to a truly large corporation.  With Yahoo!'s current Market Capitalization of nearly $30 billion, issuing another $1 billion of stock would only dilute existing stockholders by about 3%.  That's significant but not earth-shattering.

Yahoo! shares are traded on NASDAQ.  The so-called "Nasdaq 20% rule" (1) requires shareholder approval of a transaction if the number of shares to be issued is greater than 20% of the shares of stock (or voting power) outstanding before the deal (subject to some exceptions).  Three percent obviously comes nowhere near this 20% threshold.  If Y! were making a $6 billion acquisition it would likely need shareholder approval.

What about the feds, you ask?  You've seen SEC Filings by companies seeking shareholder approval for Mergers & Acquisitions, etc.  Well, yes, but that's primarily about disclosure, not governance.  For the most part, federal securities law regulates sales of securities to the public ('33 Act), ongoing disclosure by companies issuing securities ('34 Act), and securities industry participants such as broker-dealers ('40 Act).  Corporate Governance matters are mostly regulated by state law (Delaware in the case of almost all large U.S. corporations), plus stock exchange listing requirements for the minority that qualify and choose to have their shares listed for trading, as YHOO does on Nasdaq.  That said, Congress did poke its nose into corporate governance with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, after enough meltdowns of Enron- and Worldcom-sized proportions prompted public outcry, but the governance piece of SOX didn't exactly set federal standards.  Rather, it instructed the stock exchanges to go forth and regulate, and the SEC then gave its seal of approval to the resulting rules.

Another variation on this theme is a shorter post-termination exercisability period (pardon my French) when fired for Cause.  In plain English, there's a "use it or lose it" period for most stock options after separation from the company.  Most option plans allow 90 days for former employees to exercise vested options after termination (driven by tax code requirements governing Incentive Stock Options if you care).  This can be a big problem with late-stage private companies whose employees have vested options at a relatively high valuation.  Depending on the strike price and fair market value, It can mean having to come up with five or six figures cash to exercise the options (buying and holding the shares), getting slammed with tax on theoretical ("paper") capital gains from exercising the options (with no public market to sell enough shares to cover the tax), or both.  As a practical matter, shortening the exercise period (say to 30 days instead of 90) can make it significantly harder for the former employee to exercise the options, but unlike forfeiture, it doesn't totally wipe out their value.

Every suicide is preventable in theory.  Depression is a treatable condition ? although in some cases it can be chronic, severe and treatment-resistant. (For you Van Halen fans, this is called 5150 in California.)  Yet our legal system prizes individual liberty, making it extremely difficult to hold a person involuntarily for any length of time for psychiatric treatment, or force administration of medications, etc.

In practice, I wouldn't presume to speculate whether Swartz was in treatment; such questions are rightly treated as personal and confidential to the family.  What I do know (mostly from my wife, who works a suicide crisis hotline and counsels troubled teens) is that compliance is a major challenge in the mental health field.  The very forces that can knock someone out of whack to begin with can challenge their judgment regarding perceived need or willingness to seek or remain in treatment.  As with substance abuse, intervention by concerned family or close friends can sometimes overcome resistance.  No doubt in every case many people ask themselves in hindsight whether there is anything they could have done differently.  That must be incredibly painful.

As things stand today, the U.S. Supreme Court can't really do that. The two cases it's agreed to review relate to the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and California Prop 8 (2008 ballot initiative) (meant to overturn the state supreme court's finding that same-sex marriage is a constitutional right). It's not reviewing the laws of all other states that relate to gay marriage one way or another.

I'm not a DOMA expert and have no interest in drilling down on all of the law's specific effects. Broadly, it's a federal law that was intended to supersede laws in more liberal states that might otherwise permit gay marriage. If the Supremes invalidate DOMA, it means the federal government is out of the business of deciding who can marry whom on the basis of their gender. That still leaves the laws of 50 states, each of which has the power and authority to regulate marriage, grant licenses, delegate authority to perform marriage ceremonies, etc.

If the Court invalidates Prop. 8, the law in California will revert to what it was before that initiative took effect: Same-sex marriage will be a right under the California state constitution and state government officials will have to act accordingly.  That's essentially the end of the story.  In all other states, it's not that simple.  Each state will have to evaluate its own laws and court rulings on the subject, compare to the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling on the California initiative, and determine whether its own law(s) are clearly unconstitutional based on the Court's holding.  If it's crystal clear, states would be foolish to resist.  If it's murky ? or apparent that a given state's legal situation is radically different from California's, which could be the case for a multitude of reasons ? that state could hold out and refuse to do anything differently until compelled by court decisions interpreting the Supreme Court's guidance and applying it.

In practice, if politics play a role (shocking!), unless the Supreme Court's holding in Hollingsworth is exceptionally broad and powerfully worded, I'd expect at least some states to drag their feet.  Things will end up back in court at various levels in various states, and although judges won't flatly refuse to follow recent Supreme Court precedent, there will be intense political pressure (in, say, Utah or Mississippi) to distinguish their own laws from California's, try again with more narrowly worded laws or amendments to state constitutions, temporize, obfuscate, you name it.  A good historical guide is school desegregation in the South, which didn't magically occur overnight after the Court's historic decision in Brown v. Board of Education.  (Hopefully in this case the National Guard won't need to be sent in.)

I would almost always recommend forming a Delaware corporation, doing at least a basic name search, and handling the initial round of formation documents (issuing stock to founders and assigning Intellectual Property ownership to the company) before pitching to Venture Capital Firms.  It's not that this will impress them per se, but rather that getting it out of the way ? and doing it the right way from their point of view (meaning the way that's been the norm for decades), using a lawyer or firm that "gets it" ? enables you to cross off an item on their long list of concerns before investing.  It's one less thing for investors to worry about, and it's an indication that you understand "how the game is played."
 
Others may tell you it's not important, or that the form of entity doesn't matter, or that the documents are boilerplate and can be done by downloading them from the Internet, etc. They are simply wrong, and as an entrepreneur, it's reckless to place the future of what may turn out to be the greatest achievement of your lifetime at risk because you couldn't or wouldn't scrape together a few thousand dollars to get started on the right foot with a competent startup lawyer.  (David S. Rose is right in his ballpark estimate of fees.)

It's less critical for Solo Founders (although they tend not to stay purely solo for long), but for any business with Co-Founders, failure to create the basic documents covering IP ownership, division of equity and vesting terms is simply insane.  Knowing how hard you work to create value starting with nothing but a vision and your own resourcefulness, imagine toiling to build a business worth tens or hundreds of millions of dollars only to have one of your early co-founders walk away with 1/3 or 1/4 ownership after a few months of half-hearted effort.  This isn't the only example, but it's the most dramatic way to convey the point that having the right documentation in place, including IP assignments and stock vesting, is a kind of insurance policy against such unfair outcomes.

When founders ask me when to incorporate, I virtually always recommend "as early as possible."  What that typically means in practice is as early as someone is willing and able to engage a startup law firm.  There is virtually zero downside to incorporating early if it's done the right way.  After the initial legal and filing fees, until the corporation starts doing business, in most cases the only expense is annual franchise tax paid to the state of incorporation (usually a few hundred dollars; $800 in California).  Startups go through many twists and turns, but it's generally trivial to do things like renaming the corporation, increasing the number of authorized shares, adding or removing people from the Board, or changing co-founders' titles after incorporation (but before the company takes on a round of institutional funding).

There are other major benefits of forming a business entity, such as limiting personal liability, but this answer is long enough already.  I would also caution that although a Delaware corporation is the industry standard, and should never get you funny looks from VCs, there are legitimate reasons to go with other structures, usually driven by tax considerations.  Any good startup lawyer will advise you of the pros and cons, and also recommend that you consult a good tax advisor, before moving ahead.  (That said, some Startup Incubators and Seed Programs require founders to form a Delaware corporation with a standard structure before starting the program.)

To rebut the inevitable accusation by cynics of a conflict of interest:  This is emphatically not about lawyers making money.  Trust me, generating a stack of documents to form a new startup in exchange for fees that will rarely amount to more than $5K is not something that gets most attorneys salivating.  For corporate lawyers, there are much larger, more lucrative, complex, intellectually challenging, resume-building deals and projects to work on for big corporate clients.  Speaking as a startup lawyer, we do this work because it's the beginning of an exciting journey and hopefully a long-term relationship with entrepreneurs; as their needs grow by leaps and bounds along with the success of the business, ideally our practice grows with them.

I was asked to answer this question, but Jim Andelman nailed it already and David S. Rose provided the icing on the cake.  I would just add that it can be helpful to compare and contrast the concepts of mathematical vs. economic dilution.

Some people visualize equity only as a matter of percentages ? not a bad idea at inception, but it gives the misleading impression that there's a fixed "pie" that can only be sliced up into a finite number of pieces adding up to 100%, ultimately a zero-sum game.  Yet a growth company, by definition, is not a zero-sum enterprise.  As one well-worn saying asks, "Would you rather own 1% of a billion-dollar company or 100% of a worthless company?"

Dilution can be conceptualized as cutting the pie into more pieces, and cramming in more fractions entails "squishing" others' existing slices to make them smaller.  That's the concept of what some call mathematical dilution.  By definition, an equity percentage is a fraction, the denominator of which is the total number of outstanding (or issuable) shares, so adding more shares will always "dilute" existing shareholders in that sense.  Yet what matters fundamentally is economic dilution:  Will adding newly issued shares make existing shares less valuable, and if so, how much?

The simplest illustration is the first VC funding round of a new startup.  Before, it might have net assets that are essentially zero.  Suppose it raises $2 million at a $6 million pre-money valuation.  The founders go from owning 100% to 75% of the company ? experiencing pure mathematical dilution ? but they now own 75% of a company that has $2 million in cash sitting in the bank when it had none before.  That is not economic dilution, but rather its opposite (accretion).

If you read the "Dilution" section of an IPO prospectus, you'll see that the opposite happens to investors in the new public shares.  Every S-1 contains the same language that reads, roughly, "Investors will experience immediate and substantial dilution."  That's because whatever price the public investors are paying for their shares, the founders, employees and earlier investors inevitably paid less.  The economic value of the new shares is immediately diluted by the existing shares, which make up the majority of the company's stock.  The "dilution table" quantifies this effect in a way that is supposed to be helpful to investors.

Think of voluntary attrition like a car with both gas and brake pedals.  Lots of factors can motivate people to want to leave an organization (stepping on the gas), as varied as human nature.  Historically, for most successful startups, the "golden handcuffs" of Employee Stock Options operated as the hand brake that almost immobilized people from voluntarily leaving.  The more successful the company, the more valuable the golden handcuffs.  Most options vest over four years, but even if fully vested, they need to be exercised within three months after leaving the company. If you hold options in hugely appreciated stock, and you quit your job, and the stock isn't yet publicly traded, you're in a tough position. You must exercise within the three-month post-employment period, which can involve coming up with a large chunk of cash to buy the stock, or taking a huge tax hit, or both.  That's kept many people around at the  most successful startups until a liquidity event (sale of the company or IPO).

Things changed radically in the last few years with the growth of secondary markets like SecondMarket and SharesPost, as well as secondary investment funds that make money dealing in shares bought from employees at privately held companies.  Facebook made the most headlines in this area, but secondary markets are flourishing in the stock of any high-profile, "brand-name" private company such as Twitter.  So, as an arbitrary example, if I had vested Twitter options with a net value of $2 million and wanted to leave the company, but it would cost $500K to exercise the options, there are buyers who would front me the $500K (which goes to the company) and buy the stock immediately for $2MM.  Voila ? no more golden handcuffs.

I wouldn't call this "normal" in the sense of "standard practice."  In my experience, taking equity in clients is a peculiarity of the Silicon Valley startup practice; lawyers elsewhere often find it unusual, and possibly even unethical, depending on the facts.

That said, it's common among firms that do a lot of startup work (like mine) to ask for a small equity interest if they (we) represent a new company from inception. Highly unlikely, but I wouldn't say "no" categorically. This is more of a classic "it depends" issue. Key factors in my view include:

How original is the idea really?
How easily can it be copied?
How closely related is the idea to those being pursued by other startups, particularly other portfolio companies?
How much is the "devil in the details" of execution?

Lots of great material here, but I think the strongest point still needs to be reinforced:  Because Google is Google, and Quora isn't.

My answer isn't as flip as it might first sound when we examine the two major factors that this entails:  (1) the general public's sense of entitlement to use Google resources without limit, combined with (2) a sense of Google's uniquely monolithic status that makes it the Microsoft of the new decade.  Quora (company) evokes neither of these.

Consider that the largest social network in the world, Facebook (product), is (or was) a startup.  MySpace, the second-largest in the world (and the largest in its prime, with more than 200 million users), also began its life as a startup, as did Twitter, YouTube, LinkedIn, Flickr, Digg, Yelp, Foursquare, Reddit, Delicious (web application), and many others.  Every social network launched by the titans of the consumer Internet during the explosion of the social Web (roughly 2003-07) failed.  Every one.  AOL, Microsoft, Yahoo!, Google and the rest proved incapable of making significant headway in social except through acquisitions ? and even then managed to ruin some good businesses.  My point here is that there is no precedent for a large, wealthy, powerful, ubiquitous Internet company founding a social network from scratch that has scaled to truly significant proportions (tens to hundreds of millions of registered users).  If Google+ becomes truly successful, people will rightly become suspicious of the extent to which Google can mine their entire online lives for private information that is used for who-knows-what.  Quora doesn't have anywhere near that visibility into our identities and never will.

Most angel investors are successful entrepreneurs who made their fortunes by building companies, creating value, and reaping the benefits in a liquidity event. They are understandably sought after for both advice and investment capital, but advice is the lighter commitment of the two and can be given in many different forms with varying degrees of commitment.  Capital is either invested or not, and most investors have to turn down the vast majority of companies that pitch them.

It makes more sense to approach an angel asking for advice, not money, with the philosophy that you're lucky to benefit from their experience, insights and connections, and offering to compensate him or her for advisory services (usually stock options or shares of founders' stock).  If all goes well, once you've shared your vision for the company and excitement about its prospects, and gotten the advisor's buy-in, the angel is far more likely to want to invest on his or her own initiative.  See my related answer to How do you ask someone to be on your advisory board for a new startup?

I will have to go with my usual answer, "It depends." Divide things up by grade level and by type of homework:

Elementary school, for the most part, should involve little homework. I attended an "alternative" private school where we had virtually none until around 7th grade, and that was mostly done to prepare us for the impending drudgery of high school homework assignments. If young children can't learn what they need to during the school day, that calls for tutoring or extra practice outside school hours, but it shouldn't be the norm.
High school is another matter because of the nature of the subjects being taught. I would distinguish here between types of homework:
Reading at home is essential for many subjects. How on earth can you have an intelligent classroom discussion in English class about a novel if the kids haven't read it? Asking them to read a chapter here or there at home and come prepared to discuss it seems totally reasonable. You can read passages aloud in class, but reading an entire 300-page novel would take forever. Similarly, history classes involve a lot of storytelling (if well written) that can be done at home so the teacher can use the limited classroom time to focus on the most interesting lessons learned, big-picture issues, etc.
Problem sets are the thrust of this question in my opinion. Here I do think it's the case that the students who are quick to catch on can find themselves grinding through needless repetition of material they've already absorbed merely to earn credit, whereas more average students probably need more repetition to practice and learn from their own mistakes.
Papers sometimes seem like a tedious waste of time, but the truth is there's no better way to learn to be a good writer than to write, a lot, over the course of years. Given the abysmal state of writing on average these days, if anything I think schools need to focus more on writing, not less. (That said, it doesn't do much good unless teachers give thoughtful, personalized feedback to help every kid improve.)
College is like high school squared. With greater independence comes greater responsibility. I generally believed in college that most homework should be optional, ungraded (or narrative graded), for students' own benefit, allowing everyone to practice as much or as little as they needed to before midterms or final exams. There again I think some students will need more repetition to absorb the material than others.

I usually start with finding out what my audience is interested in. A great tool for this is Facebook Open Graph Search. "interests liked by people who like ________" "pages liked by people who like ________" (the blank either being your own page, unless you are just starting out or just have your mom liking your page ;) - otherwise insert pages like yours like competitors or similar products). Start reading blogs by people in your audience. Read the sources they would read. See what is most engaging. Find your audience on Twitter, Quora, YouTube, etc. and consume as much content as you can until you really understand what is engaging.

So I guess those are some tools. ;)

When you start creating content, it's not necessarily about text posts, images, videos - it's about the context. I break types of posts into different categories:

1. Product - who, what, when, where, why - these are the posts that promote or talk about you or your product directly. Keep these to a minimum.

2. Brand - how do you make people feel? These can be super engaging if done with storytelling. They are tangentially about your product, but are more about the customer.

3. Lifestyle - these are the posts that have less to do with your product and more to do with paying attention to what's happening in the world around you. Memes, holidays, world events...how can you participate in these?

4. Community - this is when you focus on your customer, your partners, your vendors and everyone else around you.

Of course, many posts span multiple types.

There is lots that goes into the creativity behind the posts - but much of it comes from step 1 - understanding your audience. But a great book to get some framework is Jonah Berger's Contagious. I often refer to his STEPPS (social currency, triggers, emotion, public, practical knowledge + storytelling) for inspiration.

All along the way, you are listening, responding, adjusting and improving. And your audience is responding in kind.

There are lots of tools to help you manage stuff (Hootsuite, Spundge, Pagemodo, etc), but the heart of it comes from what I wrote above. Don't focus on the tools. Focus on your customer.

I don't know if I agree with your 1, 2 and 3 or really think that is the reason why Swipely hasn't seen huge adoption. Blippy is steadily growing, though, and I think part of it has to do with their pivot in market. They've integrated retailers like Sephora and increased incentives for reviewing purchases, which drives more conversation.

If I was to guess why Swipely hasn't seen mass adoption, I'd say a couple of things (as a user):

1. there isn't a tie-in to other platforms. I can email something I purchased to friends, but they won't let me post it to Facebook. Blippy does. That sharing helps growth.
2. by pulling in every 'swipe', it devalues the ones that count. Something we've found out through research is that people don't want to keep track of every purchase. That coffee you bought on the way to work is unremarkable compared to the awesome deal you got on that Prada Bag. Mixing the two in one stream just ads work to the 'share'.
3. they added badges instead of really thinking out engagement. I started getting all of these notifications that I was the VIP of Paypal. Ugh. Not exactly a goal. Lots of companies unfamiliar with the social space (and Angus' previous company, although successful, wasn't social) make the mistake of seeing things like badges as the incentives. Sure, badges work for Foursquare, but the ENGAGEMENT of Foursquare is in the social aspect: "I'm mayor, bitches!" you can joke with your friends. It's highly uninteresting for people who don't use foursquare to see others gettng badges. Really engaging is harder and takes time. And you have to start with the right people...people who like to talk about and share their purchases.

Blippy is starting to figure this out and maybe Swipely will, too. There is huge potential in Affiliate alone. Both companies need to build trust with their users first and foremost (I am kind of a power user on both - with 700+ swipes/blips, but I'm an edge case) and that's going to take time.

I also don't think that these are social networks at all...this is a wholly new emerging space I call Personal Data Services. But I'm geeky that way. ;)

That's my 0.02

It sure feels like that to me -- that Box will be sold sometime in the next year or so. I don't know much about the company or the situation, but the market chatter about a Box sale resonates with me as likely to be credible.

Here's why:
The company is burning a lot of cash, and I bet that it will be more difficult to raise private capital now vs. a few years ago.
Pressure on cash flow is likely to get worse. Competition and competitive pricing pressures (including from Google) are going to make this market tougher in the next couple of years, with pressure on gross profits and pressure to spend more on sales and marketing.
It looks like there's a good chance that the cloud services business is going to evolve into one where companies offer a combination of software and storage. If Box doesn't have a terrific set of software applications coming down the pike (and they might), they are likely going to face stiff competition from bigger companies who have great software offerings (and deep pockets).
From a distance, it seems like Box would be an awesome strategic acquisition for a major enterprise software company. From both an offensive and defensive standpoint, Box would let such a company offer a better overall set of products.
Plausible acquiror candidates, include: Oracle, Microsoft, Salesforce, Google (?), HP, EMC. An auction would probably be very successful and reach a high price.


To be clear:
I'm pretty sure that this POV (more or less) is shared by many others in Silicon Valley. It might be totally off -- and Box may stay independent --  but I think it's useful to understand why the speculation is happening.
I know that I could be totally wrong; it's always tough to guess what is going on at a company. Aaron Levie may be actually hellbent on staying independent and the company may have some awesome products in its pipeline.

Moving on from DotSpots was bittersweet. We spent a few years pouring our heart into the product, which we all honestly believed would revolutionize how people consumed news. Unfortunately we underestimated how difficult it would be to get publishers to sign on and missed the window overall for success.

Another thing that's hard for me is having the great GWT-based infrastructure we built to pop up UI overtop of any webpage basically sitting idle. I'd love to open-source that one day, but it's not pressing right now. Perhaps if the right project comes along, we might be able to hand off some of it to them.

We did manage to use *some* of the DotSpots technology to bootstrap our efforts at gri.pe. The core web infrastructure for serving gri.pe pages is basically what we were going to use for serving dotspots.com.

The great part about moving on is that you have a chance to let go of all the future plans that were weighing on your mind. After a few years at a startup, you've got stuff that you've always wanted to do but never had time for. Pivoting to a new idea lets you finally let go of those in your mind.

It's also a great feeling to be working on an application that's seeing significant traction in the market. We blew by the total lifetime number of users of DotSpots within a few months! It makes you feel good seeing numbers that show people are using the application and it's making a positive impact on their lives. I would have loved for DotSpots to have a positive impact too, but it just never caught on.

In the end, it's an awesome move for us. It's still a bit sad though - like moving from a house you've lived in for years and have built memories in.
