Lifehacker's quality has not declined since I left. In fact, it has increased.

Obviously I'm not objective about this, but I'll make the argument anyway, because I've heard this question a few times, and while it's great for my ego, the conclusion that Lifehacker was good because I was there is just flawed.

Lifehacker's posts today are more thorough, more quickly published, include better art and more detailed screencasts and video segments than they ever did during my time there (from 2005-2009). They have a bigger staff and cover more beats than my staff did back in the day, too. See their very detailed coverage of all platforms: Android, iOS, Mac, Windows, Linux, the cloud. They're right on top of interesting and obscure nerd projects like running Android on an iPhone (or Hackintosh'ing OS X on a PC) as well as the new webapp du jour for doing something useful, day in and day out.

The difference between now and then is back then, the idea of "life hacks" was novel, geek productivity was a hot topic, and besides Merlin Mann's 43 Folders, Lifehacker was a whole new slant on tech. These days, GTD is no longer a revelation. The life hacks meme has cooled and seen dozens and dozens of blogs and books spring up around it. To grow its readership, Lifehacker has to target a more mainstream audience as well as geeks, and that can be a tough fence to straddle. It's really easy to lose a less tech-savvy person with one super-technical post, and lose passionate geeks with one oversimplification.

Lifehacker's main themes--productivity and approaches to it--haven't changed over the years, but the tools to achieve them have. So, for a long-time reader, it can feel like new posts are rehashes of old stuff. It's a challenge to write a site that caters to both new visitors and remains fresh and new to loyal visitors, and while it's not always perfect, the current editorial staff is doing a bang-up job-- better than I did in its first four years.

I'm not sure of its historical origin, but I wouldn't be surprised it's from the educational radio of the 50s and 60s. Either way, it's certainly passed down over the years within the culture of NPR and public radio in general. We've always prided ourselves on a delivery that's thoughtful, deliberate and clear, while not being rushed, or academic for that matter. You also won't hear us using a lot of fancy, multi-syllable words that are more common in newspapers and magazines; we really try to write our scripts so they come across as spoken English, not written English. A lot of people who work here grew up listening to NPR, and they've worked very hard to get their own pacing just right

We also offer training to on-air staff so they can work on their delivery. There's even a book called Sound Reporting, by longtime NPR producer Jonathan Kern, that talks about on-air delivery, including how reporters and hosts make notations on paper copies of their scripts to specify when they want to emphasize a word or syllable, pause for a beat, etc.

One of the biggest goals is intimacy. On many occasions I've heard my on-air NPR colleagues say they always try to speak as if they're talking to one person who's in the room with them, rather than to an audience of millions. And that intimacy comes through in their delivery.

Trust me, it's not easy. I've been on air many times to be interviewed, and I'm always comfortable with that, but the couple of times I've taken a crack at reading a script, I failed miserably. And I'm always in awe of the hosts when I'm in the studio with them, in terms of how they can take a script and read it so naturally.

I can't stand phrases like "social media expert" or "social media guru." When I go on air at NPR, I encourage the host and producers ahead of time to not use such language. I've been insistent that my title at NPR is simply Senior Strategist, period. Not because the phrase social media bothers me per se, but because I see the work I do as helping NPR achieve its mission of creating a more informed public through public engagement. And I think it's equally important for us to be engaging people offline as well as online, because our mission isn't limited to those people with broadband. Do we use a lot of social media tools in our work? Sure. But social media is just a means to a particular end, and only one part of that equation of achieving that end.

I get asked a lot how it is that Mullen transformed itself over the last couple of years, evolving from a ?traditional? ad agency into a firm that blends digital, social, media, creative, mobile and DR in a way that actually works, albeit with a bit of occasional tension and pain.

Here are what I believe has worked for us:

A philosophy summed up in a single word:  Unbound

It was at an offsite a few years ago when our management team challenged itself to re-invent the company for a future filled with all kinds of changes ? technology, social media, consumer behavior.  We came up with the word Unbound to declare that we would not be restricted by our past, by the conventions of advertising,  or even by our current skill set.  Instead we would embrace ? even more aggressively than we already had ? the idea that the answer to how we build a client?s business wasn?t necessarily advertising. It might be a new product, or the way we gather a community, or how we construct new tools, apps and platforms.

An obvious emphasis on talent

We made an aggressive investment in new talent and got out of their
way. We brought in a new ECD, now CCO.  We hired a new leader for our
account group. We added experience in our analytics group. We also
created bigger opportunities for our existing stars. One of our key criteria was how hungry they were. Those of us who?d built the company from a small regional boutique into a national agency knew how far determination and passion can take a company. We wanted the same qualities in the next generation of leaders.

A relentless focus on the work

It should go without saying, but the fact is that everything from deadlines to approvals to expediency can get in the way of a relentless focus on great work. But Mark Wenneker, the agency?s creative leader, has taken the work up more than a few notches and more importantly gotten the entire company aligned with the mission.  We?re not where we ideally want to be, but anyone who?s any good never is.  The fact that creativity, in all of its manifestations, has the organization?s collective attention is likely to yield even better work in the coming year.

A willingness to push responsibility down

Mullen has always prided itself on a culture of ?collective entrepreneurialism,? an oxymoron I coined years ago to describe our culture. I get asked a lot how it is that Mullen transformed itself over the last couple of years, evolving from a ?traditional? ad agency into a firm that blends digital, social, media, creative, mobile and DR in a way that actually works, albeit with a bit of occasional tension and pain.

Here are what I believe has worked for us:

A philosophy summed up in a single word:  Unbound

It was at an offsite a few years ago when our management team challenged itself to re-invent the company for a future filled with all kinds of changes ? technology, social media, consumer behavior.  We came up with the word Unbound to declare that we would not be restricted by our past, by the conventions of advertising,  or even by our current skill set.  Instead we would embrace ? even more aggressively than we already had ? the idea that the answer to how we build a client?s business wasn?t necessarily advertising. It might be a new product, or the way we gather a community, or how we construct new tools, apps and platforms.

An obvious emphasis on talent

We made an aggressive investment in new talent and got out of their
way. We brought in a new ECD, now CCO.  We hired a new leader for our
account group. We added experience in our analytics group. We also
created bigger opportunities for our existing stars. One of our key criteria was how hungry they were. Those of us who?d built the company from a small regional boutique into a national agency knew how far determination and passion can take a company. We wanted the same qualities in the next generation of leaders.

A relentless focus on the work

It should go without saying, but the fact is that everything from deadlines to approvals to expediency can get in the way of a relentless focus on great work. But Mark Wenneker, the agency?s creative leader, has taken the work up more than a few notches and more importantly gotten the entire company aligned with the mission.  We?re not where we ideally want to be, but anyone who?s any good never is.  The fact that creativity, in all of its manifestations, has the organization?s collective attention is likely to yield even better work in the coming year.

A willingness to push responsibility down

Mullen has always prided itself on a culture of ?collective entrepreneurialism,? an oxymoron I coined years ago to describe our culture. When you?re a small company it?s a lot easier to recruit people who share the same mindset.  The best way to find out of folks still have that quality is to give them rights and responsibility then hold them to it.  The best people want that, even demand it, and the benefits to both clients and the agency are quickly apparent.

An environment that forces collisions

I can?t put enough emphasis on this. When we moved to Boston we  intentionally designed an open environment that forced people to crash into each other. My short answer: No.

Longer answer:

1. The marginal value of the money he'd receive from a sale diminishes quickly.  (The first $5-$10M an entrepreneur makes has a big impact, but starts to decline quickly after that).  In other words, he doesn't need the money.

2. In the event he has early investors that need to exit, he can swap them out with later-stage investors.  I dont' think Dropbox has any trouble with access to capital.

3. Even if he had another great idea like Dropbox, it will likely take 5-10 years to get to this kind of scale again.  Those early years are fun and educational the first time, but entrepreneurs often don't have the patience for that the second time around.  It's quite fun playing the higher stakes game, and it's hard to go back to smaller stakes again.

4. He's actually a great CEO. One of the best I've met. So, he doesn't *need* to exit.  (This is not true of all CEOs of successful startups -- some just hit a wall and are better off selling).

5. Markets change -- quickly.  I think it's short-sighted to think of Dropbox as "just" a cloud storage company.  Just like it was short-sighted to think of Apple back in the day as "just" a computer company.  Competition increases -- but so does future opportunity. 

And, most importantly:

6. Best I can tell, he's having fun is still intellectually challenged and learning new things. Few get to where Drew has gotten -- even fewer get to where he can still go.  You don't get many chances like that in life.  Regardless of how things turn out, I doubt he would regret having taken the chance and betting on himself.

I love Jason M. Lemkin's response, but will provide some arguments for keeping your low-end plan:

1. As you grow, if you're in an attractive market, you're going to attract some disrupters.  Almost always, these will come in through the bottom.  So, keeping your low-end tier, to some degree, provides defense.  Makes it harder for someone to attack you from below.  Not impossible, but harder.  For an example of this low-end defense, check out CRM and Cloud Computing To Grow Your Business - Salesforce.com.

2. If you end up looking at potential technology partnerships (i.e. people build on your API), the customer count matters.  Even though *you* may not derive much economic value from these lower-tier customers, your partners may find them attractive.  Will certainly get your more attention.

3. You may find that having that lower-tier and customer count helps you attract and retain better development talent.  Many people would rather work on a product that has 100,000 users than 10,000 users (even though revenue may be the same).  It's just more gratifying.

4. If you're in the game long enough, you may find that the actual *people* that are in your lower-tier segments end up changing jobs and becoming customers again at their new company.  And, that new company may be a much higher value customer.
More and more over time -- but still not enough.

I'll add a couple of my must sees:

The Ring (1927) - one of Hitchcock's silent films, predates his jump over the pond to work in Hollywood - this one is all British. Which fortunately leaves us with a few less awkward cue cards and quite a bit more visual interpretation. Hitch's use of visual symbolism pops up through out the whole film. It foreshadows his future use of symbolism and shadow/light imagery that make his films such a feast for the eye.  The title might refer to the boxing ring, the wedding ring, or the bracelet of rings given to the woman in this love triangle - but either way, the camera moves, perspective and symbolism are pure Hitch and worth sitting through the silent film with a simple story. You can see the future Hitch we all know and love and see how he developed that style.



Metropolis (1927)

Fritz Lang's brilliant masterpiece is so integral to how we view the evolution of film - but most people don't realize that this was a German film.  In the middle of the post-WWI Weimar Republic, with it's extremism from communism, socialism, imperialism, and very little agreement on the right & left except when it came to feeling like the treaty of Versailles had put them forever under the thumb of its neighbors - this is a stunning exploration of the class struggle and social strife.
Whether or not the story is interesting (the symbolism of workers living below the city in the dark and the privileged elite living in the utopia is just a touch heavy-handed) the stunning Art Deco futurism is enough to keep you entranced. This is the movie that leads to the SciFi and dystopian classics like Bladerunner. It's a visual tour de force.



The Cook, The Thief, His Wife & Her Lover (1989) - with a caveat that there's some instances and imagery that are not for the faint of heart (cannibalism, violence, etc) it's still the movie that made me fall in love with Helen Mirren and 22 years later I'm still amazed at the visual masterpiece Peter Greenaway managed to create. His use of color was as stunning as Hitchcock's use of light & shadow.

Obviously I'm rather fond of visual masterpieces.  I'd add more, but I think the other answers here have already done such an excellent job that it's unneeded.  These were just the 3 films that came to mind.

I don't have any stats (yet) either. But from my own anecdotal experiences, I'd say that G+ may have drawn some users away from Quora.  While the early adopters surge from new-thing to new-thing, the core users of a site are those who find a particular 'new-thing' compelling.

At the time Quora hit its open-to-any-user wave of people following the early adopters to yet another 'new-thing', the primary alternatives were things like Twitter & Facebook (short-form media), Wikipedia (historically accurate v. requiring insight or opinion), and blogging (requires the writer to find the audience and get them back to his/her site vs. coming to a built-in community of others with specific interests.)

If Quora has a weak point, it's that the concept of editing or having your own words edited for clarity and usability is not inherently friendly.  It's the red ink pen your high school teacher used that you thought you'd never see again.

However, that weak point is also one of its strong points - so it's not going to go anywhere.  If you can't edit something, you can't improve it.  If you can't moderate an environment, you can't make it useful for those who will willingly subject their writing to critique.

Google+ allows the longer form writing that appeals to Quorites, has the built-community (with simple network expansion), doesn't have the editing, and has no perceived moderation. (Although the real-name issue clearly shows that there are rules and enforcers - they're just well camouflaged.)

I would say that Quora has lost a number of casual users to Google+ but there may be some backlash down the road when the 'general public' discovers the issues with massive, open-walled, seemingly limitless opportunity for conversation.  Some will end up here because they value the higher level of engagement on the subject matter rather than on the person discussing it.

While I was in college I made a prototype of a chat website. I wrote the long polling server in Erlang because it seemed like the ideal language for the task and also as a chance to have fun learning a new language.

I then worked on the initial Facebook chat prototype as part of a hackathon project in early 2007, along with Anonymous and Ari Steinberg. I reused some of the Erlang code from my personal project. When we decided to make it an official project and productionalize the server code, the team decided to stick with Erlang and took over the code from there.

The rationale was something like:
We already have a working prototype to start from.
Erlang is good at holding a ton of open connections, which is the hardest part of a chat service.
Erlang is easy to learn, even though very few engineers already know it.

The last point, lack of expertise, is a real weakness of the language, but it was outweighed by other factors at the time. Ultimately it contributed to Facebook's decision to move the service to C++, though even with the knowledge that it would eventually be rewritten, I think it was the right choice for the initial version because of the limited resources we had at the time. It was probably also the right choice for WhatsApp for the same reason.

See Ben Maurer's answer to When did Facebook switch away from using Erlang for Facebook Chat? for more details about why Facebook later switched.

I would suggest you start writing on your own blog first. In fact, I would urge you to write at least one really awesome post per day to get started.

If you've already done that or can showcase your writing skills exhaustively another way, it's a good idea to build relationships with key people at your target publication (writers and editors).

Pitch them your story idea, or better yet, pitch them the story when you think timing is right, and after you've checked if a similar post hasn't already appeared at the publication or elsewhere.

Contributors generally need to bring something unique to the table: expert thoughts or opinion, an angle about whatever topic that hasn't been talked about (much), data only you have, research only you've made, etc.

Editing is done by writers or editors, it can take a few hours to a few days, depending on the topic's timeliness and whatnot.

Contributors also generally don't get paid, but that's rarely the goal anyway, or else you'd be asking 'how to become a staff writer at a tech blog?'.

CrunchBase is a moderated wiki, so essentially profiles can be created and edited by anyone with a registered user account (though approval by the CB team is required for most users).

Oftentimes, writers will add a company, product, person and whatnot when they write about them, in case there isn't a profile yet. Not always, but most of the time.

The fact that CrunchBase is crowd-sourced also means that there are a LOT of companies and products in CrunchBase that none of the writers have ever written or even heard about. I hope this answers your more specific second question.

Either way, we recommend companies to create and edit profiles themselves as much as possible, to ensure the highest level of accuracy.

Speaking as an individual and not as (1) a lawyer or (2) someone with any connection to Quora - yes and no.

The language in the TOS regarding ownership is misleading when it comes to content in "common spaces," particularly questions.

First, it's totally unclear whether a question is copyrightable (and thereby ownable) - I'd argue in the vast majority of cases questions are not copyrightable, so the concept of ownership of questions is meaningless.

Second, if you assume questions are copyrightble/ownable, then yes, you "own" the original question, but the TOS (and note that it HAS to do this for the site to work) grants Quora a broad license that allows content to be modified, and also sublicensed to users. This means that, while you may "own" the original question, Quora can allow users to freely edit it, prevent you from deleting it, etc. This goes for all content in common spaces on the site. When another user edits your content in common spaces, a derivative work is spawned (and so forth as more edits take place), so ownership becomes extremely murky - after 10 edits, who "owns" what part of a question (or answer summary, or question details, or...)? This rathole is another reason why I think asserting copyright over most content in common spaces is dubious.

I wouldn't have written the TOS to emphasize ownership for the above reasons, as conceptually it's not a good way to frame how common space content works on the site.

A few reasons (you hit on one):

Admins and reviewers are pressed for time and some questions require too much editing to be worth fixing at the moment. Questions that are particularly mangled may require so much work that it's not time-efficient, at that moment, for someone to fix it.
Relatedly, there could be no way at all to fix the question. This is often the case with Survey Questions, and when we don't delete them, we leave them up but tagged so they don't get distributed beyond the people following that topic.

"Pending Review" status applies to users below a certain threshold of...something. As Achilleas said, all users are treated equally, new or old.

All new users have their answers put into the answer review queue (i.e., "Pending Review" status) until notifications have been sent on their answers enough times to give the system confidence that they know the basic protocols around using the site.

Users who are out of "Pending Review" status can be put back in it if their answers are collapsed enough times. I also suspect that downvotes and question deletions are involved in the determination, but we (the moderators) don't know the algorithm, nor do we know the thresholds involved.

All of this is done automatically by the site on the back-end and moderators have zero transparency as to movements in and out of "Pending Review" status, nor do they have any way to "flip the switch" on someone in either direction.

Any conspiracy theories about people critical of the site or moderation being put into "Pending Review" status are completely false and seem to me to be distractions from why not-new users are put into this status (consistently posting poor content).

There is also no "whitelist" of people who can avoid the algorithm; everyone is in the same boat here.

The best way to get out of "Pending Review" status is to write good content, and keep writing it, basically.

The current review problem has four variables:
The amount of content requiring review, editing or moderation - answers, questions, topic changes, names, etc to be reviewed.
The power of the tools available to a single reviewer - how much a reviewer can process per unit of time given the review tools.
The speed/power of an individual reviewer - how much a reviewer can process per unit of time, period.
The number of reviewers.

One could also imagine a variable (3.5), the amount of time a single review takes, which depends on how much editing a single review action requires - for example, if most of the questions under review require heavy edits, there is a baked in upper limit on how fast reviewing can happen.

(1) and (2) are product issues that the company will address going forward, with product changes to force or incentivize good content and other product changes to give reviewers better tools. To be perfectly clear, I think engineering, product design and automation are where the vast majority of the gains and scaling will come in the review process as Quora gets bigger.

(4) is a problem for the moderation team and the company, to figure out good ways to add reviewers to the pool without sacrificing quality.

(3) is what your question seems to be addressing, which is only a small part of the problem. Because (4) is limited by how good the reviewers are, I'd say the reviewer pool will always be at least "pretty good" in terms of raw talent in reviewing, with some outliers on the "can process stuff like a robot on speed" end.

The ways to improve (3), given that, are education/training (another thing for the moderation team and company to work on) and experience reviewing, which comes with time. But, note that (3) and (2) are symbiotic in the sense that education, training and experience are also tied to the current tools.

Given that our reviewers are all quite good and we won't recruit reviewers who don't meet that high standard, I don't think we can replace them with better people unless somehow we recruit cyborgs from outside of Quora, build them ourselves, or grow genetically engineered super reviewers in vats, none of which are feasible currently.

In terms of "positive evaluation," i.e., checking for good work:

This is a lot more squishy and has to do with how active reviewers are in the community, how well they explain edits, how involved they are in discussing issues, etc. Because all of the admins are fairly active, we develop a decent feel for this, but we definitely need more reliable processes for positive evaluation going forward, which I'll give some thought to (e.g., one can imagine some objective metrics to shoot for, like unreverted edits or edits without complaints).

In terms of "negative evaluation," i.e., auditing for errors:

It's mostly informal right now, although we're working on ways to actively audit admin and reviewer actions in a systematic manner.

Admins can check a log of all special (i.e., not available to all users) actions taken by admins and reviewers for anomalies. We can also review edit logs for reviewers, although this happens infrequently.

The primary way we "audit" reviewers is complaints. Issues can be raised with moderation (generally by e-mail to moderation@quora.com) and if anything weird pops up, we look into it. People can also just PM one of the admins if they run into something they are concerned about (I'm happy to field issues privately, for example).

On the whole, I think we've done a good job selecting reviewers, so we've hardly had any problems. To the extent we have had issues, they have been due more to lack of good communication (mostly a breakdown of communication from admins to reviewers) than with anything any individual did "wrong." The weak channels of communication is also something that we're also working on improving going forward.

One issue at the moment is that Quora is moderated (questions and answers are reviewed, spelling/grammar on questions is corrected, etc), and there is currently no human infrastructure for setting up non-English moderation teams. I'm sure there are other basic technical reasons as well, such as internationalizing all of the components of the site, making UI/UX tweaks appropriate to each international "market," and solving the very significant speed/scaling issues that would come with attracting large groups of users from many different countries.

Probably a few reasons:

Piracy - Fully digital copies are easier to pirate, I imagine, if only because you've now packaged the game up nicely for digital distribution once the encryption is cracked. I otherwise see no reason why you couldn't use the same security scheme as physical copies and have it work just as well.
Size - PS3 games are absolutely massive sometimes, e.g., FFXIII is two Blu-Ray discs worth of stuff. The demand for downloading games that big over comparatively thin pipes just isn't there. You also have a lot of PS3s out there with small hard drives that can't store a lot of all-digital games (early versions were 40GB-60GB, newer ones are 120GB, and games are often 4GB+ - most users aren't handy enough to swap their smaller drives out for a cheap 500GB drive).
Profit - Console gamers are less sophisticated than PC gamers still prefer to have physical fulfillment for "real"/"big" games; Sony's failed experiment with the PSP Go proves this out. Assuming that all-digital console game sales would work like Steam has worked for Valve is folly, as consoles tend to lag PCs in terms of adoption of new technologies and distribution mechanisms. Ergo, digital sales of major titles would probably suck and not be worth the hassle for the vast majority of games except pre-ordained blockbusters.

After a few Four Loko experiences, here are some observations about effect:
The alcohol to volume-of-liquid ratio is very good; one full can of Four Loko is equal to about five beers.
The calorie-to-beer-equivalent ratio is also quite good; one full can of Four Loko is about 660 calories. For comparison, most light beers are about 100 calories, so on a per-drink basis, you're coming out ahead, roughly.
The amount of caffeine is quite high; one full can of Four Loko is equal to about 2.5 cups of coffee when you factor in the effects of the supplements in it (taurine, etc).
The taste is generally OK, although some flavors (anything lemonade) are ghastly.
The feeling you get is unique, to say the least. Once it kicks in, you feel both intoxicated and energized - unlike Red Bull, this stuff really does give you wings. Basically, the world becomes a little more awesome while you're riding the Four Loko wave.
You also get drunk faster; two cans and most people are good to go. This is actually the main reason why inexperienced drinkers are ill-advised to drink it - they can easily consume way more than they can handle in a short period of time, and the caffeine/alcohol combo can be deadly in that concentration.
Assuming they consume limited quantities, anecdotally it seems Four Loko allows some people to avoid a bad hangover. My friends think this is because of the supplements included.

The main negative of Four Loko is that some people crash ridiculously hard within a few hours of having it. I think this is because you're combining three crashes (alcohol, caffeine, refined sugar) into one, which just destroys you once they all hit.

It's a shame they're banning the stuff, it's an interesting drinking experience, like a jacked up version of Sparks, if anyone recalls that.

Expanding on Mircea's answer a little bit, attractiveness is subjective, so the only way you can know is by gauging how lots of different people react to your appearance in different contexts. This could be anything from counting how many people hit on you, and how often, to what they say to you about how you look, to what they say to others about how you look. If a broad spectrum of people in different situations seem to think you're physically attractive and treat you as such, you probably are; as for how attractive, you can judge the magnitude of each reaction to your appearance. Crudely, I suppose, you could also take Jane's advice and see how much you get away with because of your looks, which is probably a fairly good indicator of attractiveness all things considered.

Trying to figure this out entirely on your own and in isolation is a recipe for trouble, if only because most people have a skewed self-image in one direction or another, which will color their internal mental model of their attractiveness.

The main negative of relying on external indicia to judge your own attractiveness is that those indicia will be skewed by the context. For example, to overgeneralize, in my experience others will tend to find you more attractive when you're an outgoing, positive person, and less when you're not. The best way to solve for the context variable is to get feedback in a variety of contexts, including both in-person and, e.g., on photo, keeping in mind that some people just look better in person or in photos and visa-versa.

Because it's easier and more comforting to think in line with a social group than it is to form independent opinions on a wide variety of issues, opinions that may alienate an individual from his/her social group.

I think this phenomenon is basically another example of groupthink - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gro... :

Individual creativity, uniqueness, and independent thinking are lost in the pursuit of group cohesiveness, as are the advantages of reasonable balance in choice and thought that might normally be obtained by making decisions as a group. During groupthink, members of the group avoid promoting viewpoints outside the comfort zone of consensus thinking. A variety of motives for this may exist such as a desire to avoid being seen as foolish, or a desire to avoid embarrassing or angering other members of the group. Groupthink may cause groups to make hasty, irrational decisions, where individual doubts are set aside, for fear of upsetting the group?s balance. The term is frequently used pejoratively, in hindsight. Additionally, it is difficult to assess the quality of decision making in terms of outcomes all the time, but one can almost always evaluate the quality of the decision-making process.

There is also the higher cognitive load of keeping up with and forming distinct opinions on lots of different issues; it's just easier to sign up to one party line that you mostly agree with. Cognitive dissonance will tend to take care of the rest when it comes to issues on which one disagrees with the party.

Edit: Another thing to point out is that many people who vote are single-issue, or maybe handful-of-issue voters, who focus on a small subset of issues to the exclusion of all/most others. These kinds of voters stick with the party to advance a particular agenda, sometimes to their own detriment - if you assume (maybe incorrectly), for example, that Democratic economic policy is good for the poor, there are many poor people who vote Republican because of the perception that Republican social policies are more in-line with their religious beliefs. In this sense, people are partisan because partisanship accomplishes a small set of policy goals that they feel are important enough to sacrifice all or most others.

At minimum, mechanically, counsel sits in to make sure that minutes are kept and that all board actions are properly recorded and signed-off on (like granting stock options, which the board has to approve of). I suppose one could have a non-lawyer perform this function, but that seems dangerous.

Note also that many law firms will send associates or partners to board meetings for free (i.e., no bill) because of how important it is to have a good lawyer around.

Counsel is also sometimes/often a trusted advisor to the company, and so the Board will want counsel there to keep track of what is going on and give legal and business advice when necessary.

I've heard of companies that exclude company counsel from board meetings from time to time, but I think it's uncommon to do so.

We've discussed this among the admins after some complaints from users about cold PMs, and here's my two cents:

I'm a little torn on the issue. I think cold calling generally is OK - it's a way for people to introduce themselves to people they don't know and make connections they otherwise would not have made. It's particularly OK for me if it's not just automated or templated messages, but rather personal messages to individuals seeking to connect on subjects/ventures of particular interest. I also see how some users wouldn't like to be solicited through personal messages, and would find this offensive or inappropriate.

I'd generally say that personalized "cold calls," as long as they aren't broad-based and too numerous (I'm intentionally being vague, as it's a contextual determination), should be OK on Quora.

They shouldn't be OK if:
They are "spam," i.e., identical/repetitive/templated messages sent to multiple users.
If they are too frequent or too numerous.
If they are harassing or otherwise inappropriate.

I'm on the fence as to solicitation, but I think it should be tolerated to some extent in this context; it may be that people want to be solicited for some things.

This is, to some extent, a case-by-case assessment, but it's not a behavior that I would want to see banned outright, as the current system is a good way to make connections between users who don't per se know each other.

Samir is right (of course) -- it is typical, and typically required, for every GP in a venture capital firm to have some amount of money invested in each fund.

In addition, different venture capital firms have different policies on whether GPs are allowed to personally invest (side by side with their firm) in a startup that their firm is funding.  Also, different firms have different policies on whether GPs can invest in startups in which their firm is not investing (sometimes called "cherry-picking").

In our case, we chose to implement a blanket policy that our GPs are not allowed to make direct personal private technology investments, whether side by side with our firm or otherwise.  We felt like that was an LP-friendly thing to do since it eliminated any risk that our LPs wouldn't benefit from investment opportunities that we see.  We also chose to make our own investments in our own funds subject to the same fees and carry that our LPs pay.

Here is the simple rule. Don't suck and be friends.

There are really two questions to answer when looking at a standing desk:

1) motorized vs. not -- you will not stand for 8 hours at a clip, especially in the beginning, so unless you have a place to sit and work, an adjustable height desk is pretty important. Motorized are going to take you out of the cheap range fast.

2) size: a standing desk should be free of everything other than what you need to work. There is no need to get a huge one. In addition, you should get a gel pad to stand on ($15 - $100) to reduce fatigue.

Personally, the cheapest way is to stack cinder blocks on a current desk, but the best standing desk will run you $500-$700 (before shipping).

(On a side note, I got a treadmill desk, which serves as a standing desk when I'm not walking. Not cheap, but awesome.)

If you are speaking about the expectation of return by angels specifically, then its a difficult question to ask. There are basically 4 types of angels:

Friends and Family: pure emotional investment, dont expect returns, but excited if they happen (if they have a different outlook, would suggest not taking their money)
Emotional Angels: Invest because they like the act of investing in startups. Expect to fail more often than succeed, or get a huge return on most investments.
Professional Angels: No different than professional investors. They have a plan and a thesis, and invest based on that. Expect some amount of return, but understand that they will always own a small portion of the company, and therefore will never see a huge return ala a VC.
Super Angel / Micro-VC: They expect real returns because they are probably investing other people's money. Usually have a "fund" with LPs. Treat their investments like VCs, expect to gain benefit from being in a deal very early (discounts, warrants, cheaper equity, etc.), and potentially will follow on an initial investment with additional capital, unlike other angel classes.

Who should you pursue? It depends on your capital requirements and stage of the business. Usually, the path is Friends and Family then Angels then VC. The glut of seed money has many people skipping the F/F and Angel round, but that doesnt mean that EVERYONE can do that.

Your project sounds big and like every business Ive ever been pitched "revolutionary and disruptive." I always give the same advice - dont raise money until you need to. Raising money is like putting gas on a fire. If you dont have a fire (or the wrong fire) then the gas is wasted.

When you decide that raising money is important for you, then determine your capital requirements (do you need to raise $250k or $5mm, for example), which will help you determine who your potential audience (angel vs. VC) is. Be able to articulate three things:

The problem you are solving;
The solution you are developing;
How that solution will make lots of money;

In terms of #3, its not about getting to $15mm in year three, but if there is actually a real business in a real market that can get real big (real fast). If it turns out that what you are building is important, but wont be gigantic (potential of $1B in value -- not revenue), then you will find raising from VCs to be more difficult.

Its like any other business deal. There are three parts - the hunt, the courting and the close. Its amazing how much of this is like dating. You pretend you arent interested, then you are interested, then really interested (but you have to act fast!).

At the end of the day, it really comes down to trust and relationships. The more time is spent with the entrepreneur / VC, the more likely good deals get done.

For the entrepreneur, its imperative to not just chase the money, but focus on whats important (usually control). Those times can be really exciting, but if not handled properly, will end up with bitter people on both sides of the deal.

I have a lot of respect for investors that have a thesis and stick to it, even if it means losing out on "hot" deals...
you can always take time. Any investor that is super pushy is probably not the right partner. You should do your due diligence as much as should they.

aving now done all three, here are my thoughts:

As a first-time entrepreneur, you have zero credibility. While your idea might be amazing, the truth is that you are an unknown. You have never started anything successfully, and --more importantly-- never finished anything successfully either. You have made no investors money directly, and therefore your ability to raise real money from real investors is going to be real hard.

Your company begins to get some steam, you have a killer set of advisors, and people convince you that you should raise money and go big. So you put together a list of of people you want to get to invest. As put put together that list, you realize a few things: 1) it includes only people you have heard about on techcrunch; 2) you dont know anyone on this list; and 3) have no idea how to reach any of these people on the list.

If thats the case, then an accelerator is a good move. Where else can you have some of the top investors and entrepreneurs see how you think about a problem and how quickly you can progress in a pressure filled situation? Instant credibility, and your investors will be folks that want to work with you and see you succeed.

If you decide to skip the accelerator and go after a seed round (usually ~$500k, maybe as much a million), you are pretty much pricing yourself below large VCs. Are super angels better than normal angels? Not really, except they probably have stronger and broader rolodexes but also have a much larger deal flow meaning you will get less attention. Dave McClure is the perfect example. Get some time with Dave and you will get some great direction. But getting time? Well, thats fucking hard. Angels and super angels will tend to not get involved in your business, so for some that could be a benefit -- or a detriment.

Big VC is great for a couple of reasons: 1) they have a lot of money, so if you need more time to figure out what the company should be, they will have cash for you; 2) they tend to co-invest more often with more people, so the ability to build a syndicate increases; and 3) they have strong corporate ties that can accelerate business development. On the other hand, if you arent cool; you arent getting attention. Its pretty straight forward. You need to have the ability to properly engage with a partner that might be on a dozen boards and only thinks about your company once per 4-6 weeks. Communication is paramount, and if you are unsure of how or what to communicate, you can find having a big VC investor tough. In addition, your expectations for a large liquidity event just shot through the roof. Big VCs do big exits. If you arent sure you can exit big, then you will never be able to get a big VC interested in the first place.

At the end of the day, the decision of the entrepreneur is often driven by his/her stage in his/her career, and the type of business s/he is building. Dont let your ego determine your path to investment; let your business tell you.

Originally the question was: Explain Burning Man in layman's terms.
Please, keep that in mind when reading my answer... :)

I would say that Burning Man is weeklong gathering in the desert where a bunch of people consciously go about "burning" (or getting rid of) the default set of assumptions about how the world has to be, as told to us by the (mostly western) MAN -- capitalistic, competitive, scarcity-based, hierarchical, judgmental, dogmatic, etc. -- and seeing what happens.

So, it's a week-long gathering of people who are interested in exploring a world which is about individuals producing instead of masses consuming; of people creating something of direct value to their community rather than doing whatever it takes to be able to buy stuff off a shelf that has little intrinsic value, but comes with a silly brand or logo on it.

It is a week of turning your fantasies and your imagination into reality rather than passively consuming a manufactured image that predictable advertisements try to brainwash you into believing is the only reality possible.

Burning Man is a place where accepting your and others' uniqueness, freedom of expression and right to do whatever you want (as long as it doesn't violate anyone elses rights) is highly valued.  So, in a fundamental way, it's a place that inspires people to participate instead of to spectate, to suspend fixed judgement about what is right and wrong, and to instead become immersed in the field of infinite possibilities.

The weird bits (sex, drugs, rock and roll, outrageous outfits, camps, art work, etc.) all derive from a combination of the above which results in a celebration of our collective individuality and uniqueness, instead of adhering to a socially coerced, manufactured, branded, homogenous set of norms that one institution or another (companies, governments, religions) are forcing down people's gullets in order to control them and keep them in line.

hmm... As I read the above, I see that it doesn't really do a good job of answering the question in layman's terms...  but, I guess, Burning Man is not for the laymen anyway...

It's a place for the playmen of the the highest order -- the crazy ones who believe in their god-like power to shape a reality where the purpose of life is to give and experience as much joy and freedom as possible!

I've had some success in Los Angeles.  BizRate was in Marina del Rey, Shopzilla in West Los Angeles.  Flipagram is in Culver City and as we expand, we're thinking about West Hollywood.

That said, I will never again locate my start-up west of the 405! No chance, no way, no how!  So Culver City 100% over Santa Monica.

Because I'll tell you something: the biggest fraud sprung upon the rookie entrepreneur in L.A. is this stupidity known as "Silicon Beach." 

Calling "west of the 405" "Silicon Beach",  is akin to the naming the Department of War, The Department of Defense. Sure it makes sound like a good idea, but it doesn't make it a good idea.

You see, every Angeleno knows that the lamest thing about Los Angeles is not the vacuous stares of the fit-and-brainless folks in the "industry," it's the god-awful traffic.  That makes the center of evil in L.A. the 405 freeway.  So all your moves need to consider this evil vein running through the city.

With that in mind, I feel that putting your startup west of the 405 is what the devil would do if he had control of your destiny, because that assures misery for the 80%+ of your people who invariably live east of the 405.  No amount of hypothetical biking on the beach or rubbing elbows with fellow nerds stuck in the same predicament will make up for that soul-draining commute every morning.

And no, you won't be playing beach volley-ball with the snapchatters every afternoon, because, like you, they're sitting in front of their glowing screens biding their time and waiting for the 405 traffic to die down before they can start their dreaded commute home. :)

This is because, as humans, we are limited by our minds, wherein certain concepts are just too big to fit.  The only way to deal with those is to abstract them.  And each language does this in its own way...

Here are some of the most basic of such "too big" concepts and their analogues in various languages:
___Science_____| Philosophy__| Metaphysics
1) Infinity_______| God________| Universal Consciousness
2) Randomness_| Free Will_____| Field of Possibilities
3) Gravity______| Love________| Law of Attraction
4) Zero________| Death_______| Not Being

The list goes on, and I'm sure applies to string theory, multiverse, etc... of course, it's beyond my level of knowledge to be able to explicitly map those concepts into their counterparts in Philosophy and Metaphysics.

Ever since I received my MBA from Wharton, and especially after successful exits of BizRate.com (my MBA class project) and Shopzilla, this question is a common one that I get.

So I wrote the answer on my personal blog a while ago, but since nobody  reads that, I thought I'd post it on Quora too. :)

OK, let's start with what I think you need to start a good business... (focusing on internet businesses, given our audience here...)

What it takes to make a great (internet) business:

1) A good idea
Large market
Needed / Necessary Product / Service
Viral Marketing
Increasing returns to scale (defensible position)
First-mover (nice to have)
Intellectual Property (nice to have)

2) A great team
Domain specific knowledge (MBA could help here especially if you to raise money or speak the language of finance)
Complementary skills that cover all bases (strategy, product development, technology, operations, marketing, business dev / sales, finance)

3) The guts / backing to jump and take the risk
Enough cash to get started / survive for a while
Connections to sources of capital
Back-up plan in case of failure

4) The passion / perseverance to commit 10 years of your life (time, energy and money) to the cause
Flat part of exponential curve could take years? zero-to-one is hard.
We only notice businesses when they hit exponential growth and therefore underestimate time / effort.
Examples: Twitter was Odeo, Groupon was ThePoint, BizRate.com was Binary Compass Enterprises.

That said, if you have all of the above then an MBA is not necessary.

If missing some, then here is what I found an MBA can provide:
1) Two years to find your teammates
Lots of people in business school are open to talking about starting a business (also don?t forget about hitting up the Engineering department for complementary talent!)
School curriculum leads to working in teams on business cases where you can see who has complementary skills you need
Business school is not rocket science, so it leaves you time to pursue other interests.
Top Schools (Ivy League) Advantage: Powerful people send their kids there.. top connections to sources of capital

2) Two years to work on refining ideas and picking a good one
Can take classes specifically related to your business (marketing plan, business plan, legal aspects, etc.)
Teammates will work on your project for free, as part of course work in above classes: BizRate.com was my entrepreneurship class project.

If this was 2001 I'd say DotSpots failed, but since we're in 2011, I'll say that DotSpots has pivoted....  It is now: Gri.pe.

If you want the story of why DotSpots fai... err, pivoted... Well, that's something to talk about:

Essentially with the founding of DotSpots, I made some pretty big strategic mistakes, that in hindsight, a bit of humility would have helped me avoid.

You see, in 2007 when we founded DotSpots, I was coming off the success of the >$500MM sale of BizRate.com / Shopzilla, and was feeling, let's say a tad bit over-confident...

So here's what I did:
1) I picked a market that I knew nothing about (newspaper publishing)
2) This market happened to be imploding... with everyone acting as if there house was on fire... but no mind... I had created two top 100 web properties, so we didn't need to worry about such trivialities.
3) The product we wanted to create (semantically matching distributed objects of thought to groups of newspaper articles) had a huge technical risk... Ah, but that just made it more fun for us to come to work everyday.
4) The idea was impossible to explain to anyone in under 10 minutes and without getting somewhat puzzled looks... well, that's because we're so smart and everyone else is stupid... right? (not quite)
5) No business model?  No problem... who needs one of those?  It's not like we're going to ask for outsider money (or advice).
6) And let's do it all as a fully distributed team spread all over the world working out of our homes... That should raise the degree of difficulty to a level that is worthy of a follow-up to my past success.

Surprisingly, we did manage to overcome the technical hurdle and deliver a pretty slick product, totally due to the fact that our technical team was so great.  However, on every other front we felt the pain, and there was really nothing we could do about points 1 and 2... an imploding market you know nothing about is not a good place to start a business folks... :)

So, unsurprisingly, after a while it became very clear that we would either need to pivot or get off the pot:

Fortunately we pivoted and with Gri.pe we feel that we're actually onto something pretty cool:
1) Customer satisfaction is a market I know a thing or two about (hrrm BizRate).
2) Gri.pe is a mobile, social, location-based, real-time, app in the local commerce, online to offline space.  Umm... slightly hotter market than newspaper publishing.
3) The product is dead simple technically...  in fact, the challenge now is to keep our bad ass devs happy (hopefully scaling issues will be the technical challenge keep us busy going forward. :)
4) Simplest idea ever: Gripe app let's you get complaints heard and resolved with the help of your friends and followers.
5) Business Model? We are the world's first Public Resolution company... turning negative word-of-mouth into priceless positive word-of-mouth, and bringing online customers to real world shops.  There's gold in them there hills!
6) After 3 years of operating as a distributed team, we're up the learning curve a bit and have minimized the costs of this and maximized the benefits... So all good there.

Well... there you have it and here we are.

Stay tuned to gri.pe to see what happens next.

They are all basically price shopping engines, but each came at this thing from a slightly different angle and therefore even though they ended up at the same place similar products today, their past might be interesting to anyone interested in the topic...

To that end, I'll give all you Quora viewers a brief history of these three companies from my (obviously biased) point of view:

Shopzilla (which I know most about) started off as BizRate.com (1996) with a focus on merchant ratings (BizRate at some point became the largest feedback network in the world, surveying millions of customers / month).  So, as a service we were traditionally focused on telling you not just prices but which merchants were the best in terms of service.

We also decided very early to go wide with our product selection into soft categories (like flowers, jewelry, shoes, clothing, etc.)  And, also to hit SEM  (Search engine marketing) early and very proactively, building one of the most sophisticated automated bidding systems for SEM that there was.

In fact, we became so strong in SEM that we kinda gave up on developing customer loyalty for our product and just focused on landing page optimization and SEM buys.  As a result our core service (shopping search) kinda stopped evolving and improving.

As others followed our lead, and we all copied each others "successful ideas", we all basically devolved into the same service, give or take.

Shopping.com started out as two different companies, Dealtime (1998) and Epinions (1999)... Both were very well capitalized by blue chip investors.  They ran hardest (read: burnt most cash - some $160MM+ and that was before their IPO!) and Dealtime was the biggest shopping search engine for a while, with Epinions, a late entrant in 1999, having the coolest product review product and most hype.  Epinions also were the masters of SEO and built some of the coolest tech in the space, imho.

By 2003, as BizRate.com / Shopzilla was growing quickly on the back on its SEM efforts and was poised to take over the #1 slot in terms of traffic, Dealtime and Epinions merged to create Shopping.com an entity that was big enough to go public (which they did).  Dealtime never was really great at doing anything in particular but hyping itself and raising money.  Epinions was truly an innovator in the product review space, but they launched at the exact wrong time with a soon fueding management team (different story that others can tell :), and into the dot com burst of 2000.

Cool as their tech was, Epinions didn't really have a shot.

Together, as Shopping.com, they had a great name and powerful backers, but not much more...  They still did very well in SEO due to Epinions' content, and in SEM Dealtime was just slightly above average... So, they kinda lumbered along until their blue chip investors pawned them off to eBay... who I'm sure is thrilled with their purchase today. :)

PriceGrabber was founded by some scrappy guys on a shoestring budget and just a little over $1MM in angel funding, sometime in 1999. They focused on the best monetizing categories (Computer Hardware and Digital Cameras).  They hand-manicured their listings into nice product catalogs and truly took care of their customers.  For traffic they partnered with specialist sites (like DPreview.com) who gave them qualified leads, but required a lot of hand-holding.

I would say out of the three of us, while Pricegrabber was definitely the smallest, they did build the most customer loyalty.

The problem for them was that they really didn't have any sophisticated technology.  Their systems were all semi-manual and they simply could not scale their offering / user experience into harder to categorize / catalog soft categories (It's hard to list all the vendors for the exact same bouquet of roses, since roses don't come with a barcode / sku).

As a result, they didn't grow as fast in those areas, or overall.

Still, because of their customer loyalty, they built a nice little business over time.

That said, to put a cap on this post, it's interesting that all these companies were bought by public companies within about a year of each other (Shopzilla by Scripps, Shopping.com by eBay, and PriceGrabber by Experian).

And, since then, innovation by all three has basically ground to a halt.

The simplest way I can explain the uncertainty principle it is that if you know exactly where something is (and I mean EXACTLY) then in effect it has to be still there for that moment... Therefore, you can't know how fast it's moving or in which direction (at that moment).

Conversely, if you know exactly how fast something is moving in space over time, then you can't be sure where it is at any moment, because whatever duration of space and time you pick (however tiny) to measure over, you still have to deal with an infinite number locations / moments that the object has to travel through.

Of course, I'm just a layman myself, so I say, instead of worrying to much about the uncertainty principle, joyfully embrace the certainty of being...

Originally the question was: Explain Burning Man in layman's terms.
Please, keep that in mind when reading my answer... :)

I would say that Burning Man is weeklong gathering in the desert where a bunch of people consciously go about "burning" (or getting rid of) the default set of assumptions about how the world has to be, as told to us by the (mostly western) MAN -- capitalistic, competitive, scarcity-based, hierarchical, judgmental, dogmatic, etc. -- and seeing what happens.

So, it's a week-long gathering of people who are interested in exploring a world which is about individuals producing instead of masses consuming; of people creating something of direct value to their community rather than doing whatever it takes to be able to buy stuff off a shelf that has little intrinsic value, but comes with a silly brand or logo on it.

It is a week of turning your fantasies and your imagination into reality rather than passively consuming a manufactured image that predictable advertisements try to brainwash you into believing is the only reality possible.

Burning Man is a place where accepting your and others' uniqueness, freedom of expression and right to do whatever you want (as long as it doesn't violate anyone elses rights) is highly valued.  So, in a fundamental way, it's a place that inspires people to participate instead of to spectate, to suspend fixed judgement about what is right and wrong, and to instead become immersed in the field of infinite possibilities.

The weird bits (sex, drugs, rock and roll, outrageous outfits, camps, art work, etc.) all derive from a combination of the above which results in a celebration of our collective individuality and uniqueness, instead of adhering to a socially coerced, manufactured, branded, homogenous set of norms that one institution or another (companies, governments, religions) are forcing down people's gullets in order to control them and keep them in line.

hmm... As I read the above, I see that it doesn't really do a good job of answering the question in layman's terms...  but, I guess, Burning Man is not for the laymen anyway...

It's a place for the playmen of the the highest order -- the crazy ones who believe in their god-like power to shape a reality where the purpose of life is to give and experience as much joy and freedom as possible!

You know, I've looked into this extensively out of curiosity about the same question, and actually did a presentation for Ignite NYC about it last summer (
-- keep in mind that Ignite uses a pecha-kucha inspired format so it's a little jumpy as the slides keep rolling automatically).  My answer to this question is more or less from the perspective of the Gen-Y business traveler, so keep that in mind.

I believe it's been reasonably proven through survey results that Gen-Y wants to have more workplace flexibility or at least the ability to work from home.  That could easily be construed into wanting a more flexible, nomadic life.  But you also have to keep in mind the fact that the Internet actually allows us to do LESS travel -- the buzzwords here are telepresence, videoconferencing, virtual offices, etc.  Many of the same technologies that permit us to be "anywhere" do so because they reduce the need for face-to-face interaction.  Consequently, while we may have the ability to travel somewhere and work in the process, we also have the ability to do cheap, frequent, high-quality video calls with the people we'd be visiting in that "somewhere."

I think the central tension here is between having the (informational) world at your fingertips through digital technology in a way that requires less interaction with the physical world (e.g. Google it rather than biking to the library, order it online rather than going to the store), and yet being freer to roam the physical world thanks to the flexibilities that digital technology affords.

There are also some impracticalities, which I learned through a year of traveling:
Short-term sublets are much costlier per night than longer-term ones. I found this through very deep analysis (read: I was looking for somewhere to live) of Craigslist, Airbnb, etc.  I know some people who have solved this by traveling in groups or by apartment-swapping, but that is a MASSIVE logistical headache.
The IRS and the fine folks who handle your jury duty summonses do not take kindly to, "But I'm in California for three more months and then I don't really know where I'm going."  Trust me on this one.
There are things you don't think about immediately with regard to not having a permanent or semi-permanent residence.  I ended up spending enormously higher amounts of money on food because I didn't have a fully-stocked kitchen and pantry (spices, olive oil, rice, etc.) that would otherwise permit me to cook more frequently.

And then, lest we forget, many (most?) members of the Net Generation don't have this digital privilege anyway, even some of those who are earning very enviable salaries.  I think about what my high school and college classmates are doing, on average -- teachers, engineers, doctors, lawyers, theater professionals, the occasional coffee-shop dreamer -- and face-to-face interaction is still so crucial for those professions that "the peripatetic life" just isn't possible.

I created the first hashtag on August 23, 2007 and explained the process and rationale in this blog post:

http://factoryjoe.com/blog/2007/...

Essentially there was a widespread desire in the early Twitter community to provide some means for groups to organize themselves. Many looked to the model of Flickr and other standard web-based group systems as inspiration. It occurred to me, however, that a significant amount of Twitter usage occurred over SMS or other low-bandwidth channels, making group management tedious, if not impossible. Discovery of groups while on the go was another problem.

Thus, the simplest solution was to embed the group token in the tweet itself and use functionality like 'track' to follow the topic (Twitter removed the track feature long ago, but trending topics injected new life and relevance into hashtags).

Thus any user could create a new group simply by tweeting with a word ? however, there needed to be a way to separate the "meta from the meat". I chose the hash symbol because it was a convention already established in IRC channels and on Jaiku. Any user could then "join" a group conversation simply by appending a given hashtag to their tweets.

If spammers ended up taking over a hashtag due to popularity, the ease with which hashtags are created enabled non-spammers to abandon the hashtag and move on quickly. Indeed, the very ephemerality of hashtags is what makes them easy and compelling to use in a fast-moving communication medium like Twitter.

FWIW, I never imagined that hashtags would catch on as they did ? especially since Ev specifically told me that Twitter would instead use machine learning to group tweets and that hashtags were too "nerdy" to ever go mainstream.

Killing another person should be done when there are a lack of all other options to prevent the death of others. War falls into this column (sometimes). Self defense as well.

The Death Penalty is a Punihsment
The death penalty is enforced not to defend life, not to prevent future crime, and not for the betterment of society as a whole (as many have quoted it's failure as a deterrent), but rather, it is used to satisfy the personal (and very internal) desire of individuals to punish another individual for their pain, sorry, guilt, sadness, and outrage.

If the death penalty was used to protect society as a whole, it would potentially hold more merit. The government exist to protect it's citizens. But instead it serves only those individuals who wish revenge, retribution, and emotional "closure" to a wound caused by the worst criminals in our system.

The Death Penalty Devalues Life
Our view of whether the death penalty is a positive benefit to society actually comes down to how much we value other people in our society, it correlates strongly with how much we value the life of those we do not know, in fact the life of people we may not even appreciate, value, acknowledge.

Liberals have a stronger believe that we should support each other, be each other's keeper. That we should rehabilitate criminals more to than penalize them. Over very penal system is named so because it focuses on punishment and separation from society than it does on improving the moral character of criminals and improving their ability to contribute to society.

Consider where most executions in the US take place. 13 southern states have conducted 73% of all executions since the ban was lifted in 1976.


(US executions since 1976, source: Death penalty in the US mapped)

These are of course the same states it where it was at one time "normal" for slaves to be executed. Many of these states such as North Carolina and Virginia had so called Black Codes (United States) which were basically stronger death penalty laws for blacks compared to white. At one point in Virginia there were 5 crimes that a white man could be executed for and 70 that a black man could be sentenced to the death penalty for. Clearly slavery taught much of the south to value blacks less than their own race.

(Caveat, half of southern executions come from Texas. Many of the causes of a high number of executions are magnified in Texas where elected judges have to be hard on crime, the legal system in general is less "fair" to violent offenders, and the population is very high)

I would argue that slavery's devaluing of life has continued til today. Our morals and ethics and outlooks on like come get passed along through nurturing, for better or worse.

When You Devalue Life, You Devalue Society As A Whole
If you truly view life as precious, as the most precious thing we have and will ever have, creating scenarios or reasons for why another person's life should be taken away becomes a very short list. But if you value certain people's lives less than others, you can more easily believe that the death penalty is a useful penalty. We all do this to some extent. Many would for instance sacrifice the life of someone they don't know for someone they love, forced to choose. But a mindset of devaluing those that are poor, a different race, a different religion, etc. can allow us to be more comfortable making decisions about the taking of the lives of others.

This does not mean if you believe in the death penalty you are a bigot or racist or ignorant in any way. Many whites get executed in southern states after all.

Why Liberals?
To get back to the question.

Why are liberals generally opposed to the death penalty?

Because liberals believe in a social contract ? that everyone has a right to life, liberty and property (not slavery). And that a central authority is required to maintain those rights to all. In our natural state, humans retract to self-preservation as goal number one, despite any cost to others on many levels. In general, liberals fight for the welfare of all people and an equality that would not exist without a central authority or government to protect it.

That right to life, that protection of equality is driven by a believe of valuing all people in the society and helping them not only gain and protect certain natural rights, but also an ability to understand humans are flawed. Humans make mistakes. There is a larger belief in rehabilitation and forgiveness amongst liberals.

Liberals also look at the poorest in society as being disadvantaged at no fault of their own. Conservatives believe, to a higher degree, that anyone in society can transcend whatever environment they are born into, for better or worse.

If you fight for the wellbeing of society as a whole, then you also fight to correct the flaws in that society. If you for the rights of the individual above the rights of the society then you may be more inclined to support the death penalty as a more selfish act.

This is not to say that conservatives do not care about other people and that liberals are better people. These believes are built over lifetimes from nurturing to education to friends, family, and life events.

If you know someone who was convicted of a crime and imprisoned you may build a stronger belief that criminals can be rehabilitated. If you are attacked on the street violently and mugged, you may support harsher penalties under the law for criminals. And if you have a brush with death yourself, you may value all life more, appreciating how precious life really is.

It Is Not A Simple Subject
The issue is also not black and white, liberals against, conservatives in favor. Many humans fall somewhere in a grey area. Bill Clinton, liberal and Democratic President, supported the death penalty and strengthened the federal law. The Republican Party was founded in large degree to end slavery.

Politics change just as the people they represent tend to change their views as their lives progress. In one direction or the other.

The support for the death penalty decreases each year. Last year it was down to 61%. Americans are also increasingly moving to cities more and more, just like the rest of the world. Cities are in general much more liberal populations than rural areas. Cities require more public systems for the good of the whole. As this trend and others continue, the support for the death penalty will likely continue to decrease over the next several decades.

Facebook growth suffers from this. Though they are still innovating enough to survive as the king of the hill.

But realize, most Facebook users are on at least one other social network on a regular basis. Pinterest, G+, LinkedIn, Twitter, Tumblr, etc, etc all are seeing consistent growth.

Retail Social Media

This is not to say social media for stores selling goods. Retail, as in retail politics. Hand to hand social media. Closer and closer to one on one, highly targeted messaging.

The more targeted content is the more effective the message, the ask.

Automation is getting better and better. As is CRM. Plug these two systems together and you have more relevant touchpoints with more potential customers, and excellent traffic to understand it all.

I know some people think social networks and social media tools will start consolidating, but this is not going to happen. Social media is fragmented and will remain so. There will not be another Facebook, instead there will be several Facebooks, and several tools that can help you manage those channels.

Targeting is the key. This is why FBX retargeting ads just rolled out to the Facebook newsfeed. This is why Facebook ads are so powerful, and when done right, can generate email marketing sized ROI numbers.

The real return in social media comes when targeting and consumer intelligence meet with a savvy marketer and savvy tools. Savvy because they can point highly relevant messaging to those consumers, and reap the benefits. See dark Facebook posts. See Facebook Power Editor. See retargeting.

Take a community manager. Train them how to use social ads. And you have a powerful sales machine. 

Content will increasingly be customized for a smaller and smaller audience segment.
